Justo wants to use the money he is requesting to stock his space with more merchandise. He is marries and has two sons and a daughter who is in her first year in college. To make sure nothing is lacking in their home, he has faith that investing more in his business will allow him to have a better profit.

Translated from Spanish by Eliana Colunga, Kiva volunteer.

Doña Justo Pastor vende ropa, electrodomesticos, peluches, almohadas, juguetes, floreros, toallas, zapatos.....practicamente de todo. Hasta tienen animos de vender Granos Básicos

Lleva 15 años trabajando en este negocio, comenzó con 54 dólares de su propio dinero., inicia con la necesidad de tener ayudarle a su mamá, recuerda que antes cuando era niño salia con ella a vender a la calle, de casa en casa...luego lograron establecerse en una de las aceras del mercado Central de Leon vendiendo relojes, cosméticos y cosas pequeñas.

El dinero que esta pidiendo lo quiere utilizar para surtir su tramo con mas mercadería, es casado con 2 hijos y a su niña la tiene en el primer año de la universidad y para que nada falte en su hogar tiene fe que al invertri mas en su negocio le permitira tener mejores ganancias.

loans.use: Working capital, to buy merchandise (Compra de mercaderia, Capital de Trabajo)

loans.name: Reyna Isabel

texts.es:
Doña Reyna offers a much required product: communication, something necessary every day. She also sells cell phone cards.

She has been working on this business for 9 years. She started with 300 dollars from her savings. She started with an ice cream shop and cafeteria, but as she saw that communication had a greater demand, she decided to take a chance and changed her business for this Call Center located in the market La Terminal in the city of Leon. In addition, Reyna is a single mom and she has been supporting, without the help of anyone, her two children, whom are now studying in a private school. She says that thanks to God and to the support received from you, she has been able to stabilize her business and continue so that her children do not lack in education, so they are able to be professionals and people of good.

Translated from Spanish by Eliana Colunga, Kiva volunteer.

Doña Reyna ofrece es un producto muy requerido: "La Comunicación", algo de consumo diario. Tambien vende tarjetas para celulares

Lleva 9 años trabajando en este negocio, comenzó con 300 dólares de sus ahorros. Inició con una Sorbetería y una Cafetería pero al ver que la comunicación tiene mas demanda, decidió apostar y cambio su negocio por este Call Center ubicado en el Mercado La Terminal en la Ciudad de Leon. Ademas Es madre soltera y ella ha cuidado sola sin ayuda de nadie a sus 2 hijo, quienes ya estan estudiando en un colegio. DIce que gracias a Dios y a la buena colaboración recibida de ustedes ha logrado estabilizar su negocio y desea seguir adelante para que a sus hijos no les falte educación, para que logrer ser profesionales y personas de bien.

loans.use: Working capital, buying calling cards (Capital de Trabajo, compra de tarjetas para llamadas)

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Invest in new merchandise and supplies for her restaurant

loans.name: Matilda

texts.en:
Matilda hawks (sells her products by walking around with it balanced on her head) tomato paste, rice, and oil in Cape Coast. She is going to use her loan to purchase more tomato paste, rice, and oil. They are essential ingredients in jollof rice and many other Ghanaian dishes.

Matilda will save her profits that she earns for her 3 children and to purchase a store to sell her products, so she will not have to hawk. At the age of 51, Matilda is experiencing neck pains from hawking. As you can imagine, balancing bags of rice and cans of tomatoes on your head can be very wearing. The picture shows a friend helping Matilda lift the heavy load onto her head.

Matilda is a member of the lending group, Bisa Ewurade. This group of twenty-three guarantees a loan through a group repayment pledge. Peer pressure and support provide the incentive to repay; if one person in the group defaults, the group members make up the payment amount.

loans.use: To purchase tomato paste, rice, and oil

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary owns a small stall by the ocean. She carries mostly foods used for typical Ghanaian dishes such as tomato paste, oil, and fermented corn doe (used to make a kenke). She also sells basic home necessities such as mosquito coils (malaria is the number one cause for hospitalization in Ghana), soap, and candles (the power crises causes frequent brown-outs in the country and many are not connected to electricity in the first place).

With the loan, Mary will expand her store by purchasing more stock. The profits that she makes will partially go to her youngest child’s education fees. She has six children, ages 19 to 34. The 19-year-old is currently in junior high. None of her other children completed junior high school due to financial shortages.

Mary is a member of the lending group, Kamfo Ewurade group. This group of twenty-three guarantees a loan through a group repayment pledge. Peer pressure and support provide the incentive to repay; if one person in the group defaults, the group members make up the payment amount.

loans.use: To purchase corn doe, soda, tomato cans, oil, and other products for her stand.

loans.name: Joyce

texts.en:
Joyce, 35, owns a dress and handbag store at the market in Takoradi. Although she is still has a young spirit, Joyce has been in business for 10 years now and her customers are continually increasing. She is requesting a loan so she can purchase more products to meet her customers' demands.

Currently she purchases her products from a middleman, who buys from Togo. If she receives the loan, she will have enough capital to travel to Togo herself and purchase her stock. This will increase her profits significantly.

Joyce is a member of the lending group, Kaesewokan. This group guarantees a loan through a group repayment pledge. Peer pressure and support provide the incentive to repay; if one person in the group defaults, the group members make up the payment amount. The picture shows Joyce with her group members, who have all purchased bags from Joyce.

loans.use: To purchase dresses and handbags.

loans.name: Ransford

texts.en:
Ransford is committed to taking care of his 11-year-old daughter. He owns a used clothing stall at the market in Takoradi. Currently he is traveling to Accra to purchase his stock. With the loan, he will be able to purchase 2 extra boxes (about 800 shirts).

If Ransford builds up enough capital, he will travel further, where he will be able to purchase used clothing at a better price. Eventually Ransford would like to be able to support his daughter and his friends if they are ever in need of a loan themselves.

Ransford is a member of the lending group, Annointed Vessel. This group guarantees a loan through a group repayment pledge. Peer pressure and support provide the incentive to repay; if one person in the group defaults, the group members make up the payment amount.

loans.use: To purchase two boxes of used clothing (about 800 shirts).

loans.name: Juliano

texts.en:
Juliano, 45, is the mother of Kwesi, 5 (in picture above), and twin boys, 22. The twins are currently studying at the University of Cape Coast. Juliano hopes to earn enough money to support all of them through their education.

Right now Juliano is selling clothing, shoes, and cloth. She has customers all around Takoradi where she delivers her products. With her loan, Julaino hopes to purchase more stock in order to meet her customers' demands.

Juliano is a member of the lending group, Kaesewokan. This group guarantees a loan through a group repayment pledge. Peer pressure and support provide the incentive to repay; if one person in the group defaults, the group members make up the payment amount.

loans.use: To purchase clothes, shoes and cloth

loans.name: Del Tul Group

texts.es:
Among the many qualities of the clients of ComUnidad del Tul (term that Friendship Bridge uses to describe a Communal Bank), there is one that is worth emphasizing – the harmony that exists between the two different ethnic groups: Mayas Kachikeles and ladinas (descendents of Europe), that constitute the group. It is remarkable to see women that belong to different cultures work, organize themselves and get along so well. This characteristic particularly stands out when the Board of Directors, which consists of ladina and Maya Kachikel women, work together in a harmonious and effective manner.

The great majority of these women were weavers before receiving their first loan through Friendship Bridge. Many of them helped their mothers embroider huipiles (traditional Guatemalan dresses). However, with the loan they will receive from Kiva, our clients have chosen to change their path toward a more prosperous one.

At this time, the women of del Tul are investing their money in a variety of economic activities. For example, CarmeL. S. has been investing her loan in a toy store, MicaeL. J. in her convenience store, Rosa Ajpuac in her bakery, and Blanca U. in her candle and decorations store. Irma C. will invest in buying 300 roosters and hens, which she buys at 40 quetzales and then resells for 60 quetzales. Finally, another interesting initiative is that of Ana Sologui, who invests her money in her small parceL. (land plot) for harvesting coffee, which is then exported to Mexico and El Salvador.

The dreams of many of these women are centered on enabling themselves to buy a small plot of land where they can build a house or expand their respective homes, being that a small house is not adequate for their sizeable families. Delmy D. León said: “I would like to buy a plot because my house is not large enough for my family.” Delmy has eight children. Suseth G. would like to buy two cuerdas (1 cuerda = 25m x 25m) of coffee for her son. Finally, CarmeL. told her group that she would love to buy a car to be able to work in a more efficient and less sacrificed manner and to travel. These women have a lot of hope in life and in God, being that they have been given an opportunity to succeed. It is for this reason, that they should be supported so that they may continue having that hope.

This picture was taken during a pre-qualifying credit reunion.

One of the members of this group could not attend the reunion for medical reasons. She had to go to the Sololá hospital.

Translated from Spanish by Evelyn Garcia, Kiva Volunteer.

Dentro D. las muchas cualidades que tienen las clientas D. L. ComUnidad del Tul (término que utiliza Friendship Bridge para describir a un Banco Comunal) hay una que cabe destacar, L. armonía que se vive entre las dos distintas etnias: Mayas Kachikeles y ladinas (descendientes D. Europeos) que constituyen el grupo. Es remarcable ver a señoras que pertenecen a distintas culturas trabajar, organizarse y llevarse tan bien. Está característica sale a relucir sobre todo cuando L. Junta Directiva, compuesta por señoras ladinas y Mayas Kachikeles, trabajan juntas D. una manera armoniosa y eficiente.

L. gran mayoría D. señoras fueron tejedoras antes D. recibir su primer préstamo en Friendship Bridge. Muchas D. ellas ayudaban a sus madres a bordar huipiles (traje tradicional Guatemalteco). Sin embargo, con el préstamo que van a recibir D. Kiva, nuestras clientas han escogido cambiar D. rumbo hacia uno más prospero.

En estos momentos, las mujeres del Tul están invirtiendo su dinero en una variedad D. actividades económicas. Por ejemplo, CarmeL. S. ha estado invirtiendo su préstamo en una tienda D. juguetes, MicaeL. J. en su tienda D. consumo diario, Rosa Ajpuac en su panadería, Blanca U. en su tienda D. velas y adornos. Irma C., va a invertir su dinero para comprar 300 gallos y gallinas los cuales los compra a cuarenta quetzales y luego los revenD. a 60 quetzales. Finalmente, otra iniciativa interesante es L. D. Ana Sologui quien invierte su dinero en su pequeña parceL. D. café, el cual es exportado a México y a El Salvador.

Los sueños D. muchas D. estas señoras están concentrados en L. idea D. poder comprar un terrenito para poder construir su casita o para poder ampliar su respectiva casita ya que una pequeña casa no le alcanza para sus cuantiosas familias. Delmy D. León dijo: me gustaría comprar un terrenito porque L. casa ya no alcanza para mi familia.” Delmy D. León tiene ocho hijos. Suseth G. le gustaría comprar dos cuerdas (1 cuerda = 25m por 25m) D. café para su hijo. Finalmente, Carmelo contó al grupo que a elL. le encantaría comprar un carro para poder trabajar D. una manera más eficiente y menos sacrificada y para viajar. Estas señoras tienen mucha esperanza en L. vida y en Dios, ya que se les ha dado una oportunidad para seguir adelante. Es por eso que se les debería D. apoyar para que sigan teniendo esta esperanza.

L. foto fue tomada durante una reunión D. pre-crédito

Una D. las integrantes del grupo no pudo asistir a L. reunión por razones médicas, tuvo que ir al hospital D. Sololá

loans.use: Purchase capital to supply a toy store, a convenience store, a bakery, a candle and decorations store, a chicken reselling business, a coffee-growing parcela and other businesses in an effort to provide their families with more adequate housing and transportation.

payments.comment: Due to technical problems the amoun repaid by the Trust bank Del Tul were not posted. Nevertheless, these women are doing great. They all have paid on time, which is a sign of success and are saving a little income extra!

loans.name: Khan Mohammad

texts.en: Khan Mohammad lives in district 8 of Kabul, Afghanistan. He is married with one son and lives together with his father and mother. He is the only to support his family. He has a car parts shop and he has good experience. He had his own car parts shop in Iran for about 7 years and when he came back last year he started his business in Kabul. Now he would like to increase his business so he requested an individual loan to complete his stock and make a good monthly income to help his family and help his father and mother. He is happy about this loan.

loans.use: To complete his stock

loans.name: Ahammd Farid

texts.en: Ahammd Farid lives in district 8 of Kabul, Afghanistan. He is with two children. He lives with his own family. He has a retail shop and he has been involved in this business more than 4 years now. He wants to enlarge his shop so he wants to take an individual loan to complete his stock and increase his business so that he can make a good income for his family and help them better. He is happy about this loan and he would like to thank AFSG.

loans.use: To complete his stock

loans.name: Yani

texts.en: Yani is 24 years old and is a mother of 6 year old son.  She has been in the fish livestock business since becoming a member of MBK. Her husband is an employee with small salary. She requests this loan to begin the business and wants to add her income to finance her children's education. She is willing to pay this loan within period of 12 months

loans.use: To add working capital

loans.name: Lia

texts.en: Lia is 20 years old and single. She lives with her family. She sells clothes on credit. She has to support her family and helps her parents to cover their daily needs. She usually earns $10 per week and requests this loan to expand her business. She works very hard for her brother's education. She is willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: To expand her business

loans.name: Yayah

texts.en: Yayah is 25 years old, mother from child aged 4. Selling clothes on credit is her business. But she also has a food stall which sells foods, vegetables, mineral water, etc. She usually earns $3 per day. She requests  this loan to expand her business and to fill her small stall. Her husband A. is a driver who has small income. She is a member of MBK and willing to repay this business within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: To expand her businesses

loans.name: Kiki

texts.en: Kiki is 32 years old married woman. She  has been selling flowers since being a member of MBK.  Her husband is a worker who has small income. She has to work hard to cover their daily needs. She requests thisloan to expand her business to earn more income so that she could finance her children's education. She is willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: To expand her business

loans.name: Dian

texts.en: Dian is 21 years old and is a mother of a child aged 3. She sells detergents on credit by going around to various places. She can earn $5 per week. Her husband is a driver who does not have a steady job. She requests this loan to expand her business by  buying more goods to earn more income. She is a member of MBK and willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: To buy more goods

loans.name: Siti

texts.en: Siti J. is 35 years old and is a mother of a child aged 9. She sells some snacks and household goods in her small shop. She usually earns $5 per day and needs this loan to expand her business a, to fill her shop and make it sustainable. Her husband Jarnuji is a Driver who earns $30 salary per month. She wants to earn extra income for her family and is willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: To expand her business

loans.name: Aas

texts.en: Aas is 42 years old and is a mother of a child aged 12.  She has a small shop which sells some snacks, candies, household etc. She usually earns $5 per day. Her husband R. sells vegetables in the market and usually does not get much income. She requests this loan to fill her shop so that she could earn more income for her children's education. She is willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: To fill her shop

loans.name: Sugeng

texts.id:
Acivities in Sugeng's business include: maiking and printing invitation letters, business cards, passbooks, etc. He runs his business from his rented roo. His room is in Pulau Bantana street, at a rent of Rp300,000.00/month (Translator's note: 1 US$ fluctuates between Rp9000-9500.00). He lives in a small room, with a small kitchen, inside bathroom and a terrace. He works in the terrace. Although the place is not large, he sees a good future prospect. That is why he likes to expand his business, and get a larger place. Sugeng has customers who comes to his place. His daily income is betwwen Rp 300,000-500,000.00).

Translated from Bahasa Indonesia by Gwan Liong Ang, Kiva volunteer.

Kegiatan usaha yang dilakukan Sugeng, antara lain : membuat dan mencetak surat undangan, kartu nama, buku tabungan dan juga yang lain. Dia melakukan kegiatan usahanya di tempat kosnya. Dia kos di Jl. Pulau Batanta dengan biaya sewa Rp 300.000,00/bulan. Dia tinggal di sebuah kamar yang sempit, dapur kecil, kamar mandi dalam dan tersedia sedikit teras di depan kamarnya. Di teras inilah Sugeng bekerja. Meskipun tempatnya tidak luas, tetapi dia melihat prospeknya ke depan sangat bagus. Oleh karena itu untuk mengembangkan usahanya ini, dia berusaha untuk mendapatkan tempat yang lebih luas. Sugeng sudah memiliki pelanggan yang sering datang ke rumahnya. Pendapatannya setiap hari berkisar antara Rp 300.000,00 – Rp 500.000,00.

loans.use:
To maintain printing machine and screens

Pemeliharaan mesin cetak dan sablon

loans.name: Sunariyah

texts.id:
Sunariyah together with husband - Supar- has a simple life. They live in a self built hut with triplex and woven bamboo walls. They rented the 2 are land they live on for Rp1,500,000/yr (translator's note: 1 US$ fluctuates between Rp 9000-9,500). This hut is a also the place where they run the business. Every day Sunariyah opens her food stall from 7:00 AM to 9:00 PM. Her husband is helped by Sunariyah's food stall. As a construction coolie worker, he is not always working - depending on projects, with income of about Rp45,000.00. Daily living cost Rp25,000, and children's education cost of Rp75,000 is not a small amount. Though her food stall, Sunariyah is able to profit up to Rp50,000.00. One child who just move to Middle school will need higher expense.

Translated from Bahasa Indonesia by Gwan Liong Ang, Kiva volunteer.

Kehidupan Sunariyah bersama dengan suaminya – Supar - sangat sederhana. Dia tinggal di sebuah rumah yang dibangunnya sendiri dengan rumah berdinding triplek dan bedeg. Dia mengontrak tanah tempat dia tinggal seluas 2 are dengan biaya sewa Rp 1.500.000,00/ tahunnya. Rumah ini pula dia jadikan tempat mengelola usahanya. Setiap hari Sunariyah menjalankan warung makanannya mulai dari pukul 7 pagi sampai dengan pukul 9 malam. Suaminya merasa terbantu dengan usaha warung Sunariyah. Sebagai kuli bangunan yang tidak selalu bekerja – tergantung ada tidaknya proyek – dengan penghasilan Rp 45.000,00. Biaya hidup per hari Rp 25.000,00 dan biaya pendidikan anak per bulan sebesar Rp 75.000,00 tentu bukan nilai yang kecil. Melali usaha warung makanan ini per hari Sunariyah mampu memperoleh keuntungan mencapai Rp 50.000,00. Tanggungan satu orang anak yang sudah menginjak bangku SLTP (Sekolah Lanjutan Tingkat Pertama) tentu membutuhkan biaya yang lebih besar.

loans.use:
To buy materials for kiosk

Membeli bahan - bahan untuk di warung

loans.name: Hari

texts.id:
Hari rents land about 1.5 are. In that land he personally made a building for business, as well as rooms for him and his helpers. Since 2004, he is in Furniture business. Starting with 4, now he has 8 helpers. Raw materials are bought from Building stores in Denpasar. This business could bring profit of about Rp3000,000.00/month (Translator's note: 1 US$ fluctuates between Rp9000-9500.00). Customers are people surrounding his business location. Also friends of customers. Transportation used are motorcycle or pick up. Hari is married and is blessed with 2 children. The 2 childrens lives in Java island with their grand parents. Daily living expense Rp30,000. Children's education expense about Rp500,000/6 months.

Translated from Bahasa Indonesia by Gwan Liong Ang, Kiva volunteer.

Hari mengontrak tanah seluas ± 1.5 are. Di tanah tersebut dia membangun sendiri bangunan untuk tempat usaha sekaligus kamar untuknya dan anak buahnya. Mulai tahun 2004 dia menekuni usaha Furniture. Mulai dari 4 orang anak buah sampai dengan sekarang dia memiliki 8 anak buah. Bahan baku dibeli dari toko - toko bangunan yang ada di Denpasar. Usaha ini memberikan keuntungan per bulan mencapai Rp 3.000.000,00. Pelanggannya merupakan warga sekitar lokasi usahanya. Selain itu dia juga memiliki langganan yang berasal dari teman – teman dari langganannya tersebut. Sarana transportasi yang digunakan berupa sepeda motor dan sebuah mobil carry bak. Hari sudah menikah dan dikaruniai dua orang anak. Kedua anaknya tinggal di Jawa dengan neneknya. Biaya hidup per harinya Rp 30.000,00. Sedangkan biaya pendidikan anak Rp 500.000,00/6 bulan.

loans.use:
To buy raw materials

Membeli bahan baku

loans.name: Thi Nhuan

texts.en: Ms Nhuận is 49 years old. She lives in Phú Mẫn hamlet, Yên Phong, Bắc Ninh. She used to buy waste material like copper, brass, and metal and resell it to recycling companies. Today she raises chickens. She has a peep of more than 100 egg-laying chickens. She sells the eggs, and this is the main revenue for her family. She wishes to have the money to buy more chicken feed. She has applied to binhminh cdc (SEDA) for a loan, and she plans to pay the loan back in 6 months.

loans.use: To purchase feed for chicken.

loans.name: Kristina

texts.id:
Every morning Kristina goes to the market to buy raw materials to make green beans. After processing. and ready, she sells it around by motorcycle from 10:00 AM to 5:00 PM. Daily profit is about Rp50,000 (Translator's note: 1 US$ fluctuates between Rp9000-9500). Kristina is running this business with husband - Jamin. So far they do not have children yet, so that it is a good time to expand the business. daily living cost is about Rp20,000; while rental for 2 are land is about Rp500,000.

Translated from Bahasa Indonesia by Gwan Liong Ang, Kiva volunteer.

Setiap pagi Kristina pergi ke pasar untuk membeli bahan membuat kacang ijo. Setelah dia olah dan siap untuk dibawa, dia menjualnya berkeling dengan sepeda motor mulai pukul 10 pagi sampai dengan pukul 5 sore. Keuntungan yang diperoleh setiap harinya senilai Rp 50.000,00. Kristina menjalankan usaha ini bersama suaminya – Jamin. Saat ini merE. masih belum memiliki tanggungan anak, sehingga merupakan waktu yang tepat untuk mengembangkan usaha kacang ijo yang sekarang ini merE. tekuni. Biaya hidup per hari merE. sebesar Rp 20.000,00. Sedangkan biaya kontrak tanah setahun senilai Rp 500.000,00 dengan luas 2 are.

loans.use:
To buy raw materials

Membeli bahan baku

loans.name: Sri

texts.id:
H. is in this business since 2002. At one time she had 2 stalls, however one kiosk has to be closed. This was a direct effect of the Bali bombing, that resulted in reduced customers. The kiosk she still worked on today is in front of her house selling Grilled Fish and Chinese Food at Sidakarya street. Besides serving customers at the stall, H. also accept catering which is delivered directly to orderer's home. Daily income reach between Rp 200,000-500,000 (Translator's note: 1 US$ fluctuates between Rp9,000-9,500). Besides a helper, her husband is also helping her. H. bought raw materials in Badung and Pemecutan markets. Mode of transportation to buy raw materials and deliver orders are by motor cycle. Loan to be obtained are expected to expand the business. H. is blessed with 3 children. Two is at school in Java island at an education cost of Rp500,000/month. The smallest one lives in Bali wit the parents at a daily cost of Rp50,000.

Translated from Bahasa Indonesia by Gwan Liong Ang, Kiva volunteer.

H. menekuni usaha ini sejak tahun 2002. Dia sempat mengelola 2 warung, namun satu warung harus ditutup. Hal ini pengaruh dari bom Bali yang mengakibatkan pelanggan jadi menurun. Warung yang masih dia kelola sampai saat ini ada di depan rumahnya - warung Ikan Bakar dan Chinese food – di jalan Sidakarya. Di samping melayani pelanggan yang datang sendiri ke warung, H. juga melayani pesanan yang diantar langsung ke alamat pemesan. Dalam sehari pendapatannya berkisar antara Rp 200.000,00 – Rp 500.000,00. Selain satu orang tenaga kerja, suaminya juga ikut membantunya. H. membeli bahan bakunya di Pasar Badung dan atau di Pasar Pemecutan. Sarana transportasi pembelian bahan mentah maupun pengantaran pesanan dia menggunakan sepeda motor. Pinjaman yang dia peroleh diharapkan dapat membantunya untuk mengembangkan usaha. H. dikaruniai 3 orang anak. Dua orang anaknya sekolah di Jawa dengan biaya pendidikan Rp 500.000,00/bulan. Sedangkan yang paling kecil tinggal di Bali bersama orang tuanya dengan biaya hidup per hari Rp 50.000,00.

loans.use:
To buy materials needed for stall

Membeli barang - barang kebutuhan warung

payments.comment: Repayment to reflect client has fully repaid loan.

loans.name: Suharni

texts.id:
Using a motorcycle Suharni daily goes to the market about 2 km from her home. She goes to market to buy materials to make meatballs. Arriving at home she process those materials to meatballs ready for sales. Around 2:00 PM she sells those meatballs by motorcycle to the areas surrounding Gianyar until 8:00 PM. Every day she received profit of about Rp15,000.00 (Translator's note: 1 US$ fluctuates between Rp9000-9,500.00). She runs this business with her husband. One child age 4, with living expense of Rp15,000 could still be paid. However, with time they have to think about their future, and child's future. Income from metballs sales are their only source for their livelihood. To expand their business they needed borrowed capital. They hope the Rp 1000,000 to be loaned would help.

Translated from Bahasa Indonesia by Gwan Liong Ang, Kiva volunteer.

Menggunakan sarana sepeda motor Suharni setiap pagi pergi ke pasar yang terletak ± 2 km dari tempat tinggalnya. Dia pergi ke pasar untuk membeli bahan – bahan membuat bakso. Sesampai di rumah dia mengolah bahan – bahan tersebut sampai menjadi bakso yang siap untuk dijual. Kira – kira pukul 2 siang dia berkeliling menjual bakso dengan mengendarai sepeda motor di daerah sekitar Gianyar sampai dengan pukul 8 malam. Setiap hari keuntungan yang diperoleh senilai Rp 15.000,00. Usaha ini dijalankan berdua bersama suaminya. Satu orang anak berumur 4 tahun dan biaya hidup per hari Rp 15.000,00 masih mampu mereka penuhi. Namun, seiring waktu mereka harus memikirkan masa depan mereka dan anak mereka. Pendapatan yang mereka peroleh dari usaha jual bakso ini merupakan satu - satunya tumpuan hidup mereka. Untuk mengembangkan usaha mereka mereka memerlukan pinjaman modal. Pinjaman senilai Rp 1.000.000,00 yang mereka peroleh diharapkan dapat membantu.

loans.use:
To buy materials to make Meatballs

membeli bahan untuk membuat bakso

loans.name: Zuhra

texts.en: Zuhra S. is married and lives with her 3 children in Spitamen. She first became a client in 2006, and she used her loan to increase the volume of her products and increase her customer base. She prides herself on being accurate and responsible, and this makes her an excellent business woman. She has decided to apply for another loan so that she can diversify her products in order to  more effectively meet customer demand.

loans.use: Business expansion

loans.name: Vahob

texts.en: Vahob S. owns a food shop in the Spitamen district of Tajikistan. He is an active client of Microinvest. He first received a loan in 2006 which he used to expand his business and increase his customer base. Vahob S. is now applying for this loan so that he can diversify his stock so that he can meet customer demand more effectively.

loans.use: Business development

loans.name: Philip

texts.en:
At Moree Junction near Cape Coast is a well-known carpentry shop called “Talented Creative Furniture”. The owner of this business is Mr. Philip Q. who makes all kinds of furniture for both private and public organizations, schools, and his individual clients. Philip has eleven apprentices studying under him. He is 36 years of age and married with three children aged 11, 9, and 5 years respectively. His wife is a trader who sells provisions such as milk, milo, soap etc.

He is also a member of a lending group called “Emmanuel Traders Group.” The members of this group have known each other for many years, and they provide support for each other as they are all located at the same place – Yamoransa – on the Accra Highway.

One challenge that Philip faces is that organizations and individuals always ask him to make furniture for them, but because of the high cost of wood, foams, leathers, and the materials used, he sometimes loses his customers to his competitors because they have been able to secure loans from some financial organizations. As a result, Philip needs a loan of US $1,100 dollars to purchase wood, foams, leathers, nails, and the material used to manufacture the furniture in order to meet the demands of his customers.

loans.use: Philip needs a loan of US $1,100 dollars to purchase wood, foams, leathers, nails and the material used to manufacture the furniture in order to meet the demands of his customers.

loans.name: Gulchehra

texts.en: Gulchehra S. is a 44 years old woman, married with three children. She lives in Spitamen district, in Tajikistan. She first applied for a loan from MicroInvest in 2004, when she received a loan of 300 somoni (roughly $100). Since that time she has proved herself as an enthusiastic, determined and capable woman. She is very particular about paying back her loan on time, and she considers this to be one of her best attributes. She has applied for this loan so that she can expand her inventory and diversify the products that she sells so that she can more effectively meet customer demand.

loans.use: Business expansion

loans.name: Christian Rural

texts.en:
Salamatu Abdulai sells cosmetics, lace materials, thread, needles, handkerchiefs, baby diapers, pampers and provisions such as milk, soap, minerals etc. Salamatu is married and has three children ages 15, 6 and 3 years. Her husband is an electrician but his income is low. Salamatu works very hard. To help with the family finances, she also sells shoes and mineral water. Her store is located at moree junction, about 5km from cape coast. 
She is also a member of a lending group called “Emmanuel Traders Group” located on the Yamoransa – Accra highway.
Salamatu is asking for a loan of US $ 800 dollars to fill her store with cosmetics, shoes, baby dresses, minerals, laces materials, thread and provisions such as milk, milo, soap, bags of rice etc. she intends to pay the loan back within seven months.

loans.use: Salamatu is asking for a loan of US $ 800 dollars to fill her store with cosmetics, shoes, baby dresses, minerals, laces materials, thread and provisions such as milk, milo, soap, bags of rice etc.

loans.name: Christian Rural

texts.en:
Gabriel Arthur is a fridge repairer and also sells “home used fridges” (second-hand fridge) imported into the country from Europe. He is 35 years of age and married with three children ages 12, 5 and 6 months baby. The wife is a trader who sells provisions such as milk, soaps, milk etc. Gabriel is a hardworking man. To help with the family finances, he also sells fridge motors. His shop is located at moree junction, on the Yamoransa – Accra highway. Gabriel has suppliers who always supplies him with fridges and the fridge motors and he is also a well known fridge repairer. He also repairs air conditioners.
He is asking for a loan of US $ 800 dollars to enable him renovate his shop, buy more fridges and fridge motors from his suppliers and also, to buy air conditioner gas.

loans.use: He is asking for a loan of US $ 800 dollars to enable him renovate his shop, buy more fridges and fridge motors from his suppliers and also, to buy air conditioner gas.

loans.name: Subgroup D Of Group Sungura

texts.en:
Hellen, age 26, is the leader of Subgroup D of group Sungura (Swahili for “rabbit”), which totals 31 members. Hellen owns a beauty salon which she opened in 2004. Before starting this business, she worked as an assistant hairdresser in other salons. Now her salon brings in around 10-15 customers a day and makes about $35-45 a week. Her sister assists her in her work. She lives with her sister and brother at their relatives’ home.

Hellen will be sharing this loan with her subgroup members Mwamtumu B. (selling fruits), Godfrey M. (selling fruits), Juma M. (photographer), Martha M. (selling chicken), and Stella J. (honey vendor). This subgroup has taken out 3 previous loans from Tujijenge Tanzania to enhance their businesses, and they were able to pay each back successfully.

Hellen used the previous loans to pay for her sister’s school fees and to enhance her business. With the new loan, she hopes to purchase more hair treatments and a new hair dryer. Her ultimate dream is to one day open a pharmacy.

In the picture, Hellen is the woman standing next to the man on the far right.

loans.use: To buy hair salon treatments and equipment

loans.name: Obed Uche

texts.en:
Mr. Obed Uche M. 34 years old, is married with 2 children, and lives in Benin City. He sells electrical appliances. He worked with someone for 2 years to learn the business. Then he opened his own business in 2001.

Mr. M. requests a loan of $600 to buy more deep freezers, microwaves, and cookers to sell. He is a member of LAPO. He thanks you.

loans.use: Buy more appliances to sell

loans.name: Rita

texts.en:
Mrs. Rita O. is 40 years old, is married with 3 children, and lives in Benin City. She has a store where she sells wrappers. She worked with someone for 3 months to learn the business, and then started her own business in 2006.

Mrs. O. requests a loan of $875 to buy more wrappers and clothes to sell. She is a member of LAPO.

loans.use: Buy more wrappers and clothes to sell

loans.name: Charity

texts.en:
Mrs. Charity O. sells women's clothes to the people living in her community. She started her business in 2005.

She is 37 years old, married with 4 children, and lives in Benin City.

Mrs. O. requests a loan of $525 to buy more clothes to sell. She is a client of LAPO.

loans.use: Buy more clothes to sell

loans.name: Vicky

texts.en:
Mrs. Vicky A. is 32 years old, is married with 2 children, and lives in Benin City.

She sells women's clothes. She worked with someone for 6 months to learn the business, and then opened her own store in 2003.

Mrs. A. requests a loan of $450 to buy more women's clothes to sell. She is a member of LAPO.

loans.use: Buy more women's clothes to sell

loans.name: Christiana

texts.en:
Mrs. Christiana E. is 42 years old, married with 9 children, and lives in Benin City, She sells bush meat. She learned the business from her mother.

Mrs. E. requests a loan of $450 to buy more bush meat. She has been a LAPO client for 7years, and she thanks you.

loans.use: Buy more bush meat to sell

loans.name: Eunice

texts.en:
Mrs. Eunice A. is 35 years old, married with 3 children, and lives in Benin City. She is a professional hairdresser. She worked with someone for 3 years to learn the business, and then started her own salon in 2000.

Mrs. A. requests this loan to buy more Weavons to sell. She has been a client of LAPO for 4 years.

loans.use: Buy more Weavons to sell

loans.name: Clara

texts.en:
Mrs. Clara U. has a business selling Garri. She goes to villages to buy Garri in large quantities, and then sells it to her customers in the city.

She worked with someone for 6 months and then started her own business in 1995. Mrs. U. requests a loan of $450 to buy more Garri to sell.

She is 44 years old, is married with 5 children, and live with her family in Benin City. She has been with LAPO for 4 years.

loans.use: Buy more Garri to sell

loans.name: Christian Rural

texts.en:
Alex K. Gurah is a welder at Moree junction near cape coast. He has his own shop. He is also married with four children ages 12, 8, 6 and 2 years respectively. The wife is a trader and she sells foodstuffs. Alex also manufactures baking ovens, coalpot (traditional stove used for cooking here in Ghana). He has lots of customers. In addition to this, Alex also sells car plates. At Alex shop, lots of car has been parked there awaiting body works (maintenance). He also has three apprentices understudying him.
One major challenge that Alex faces is that most of his customers do not make full payment when they bring their cars to him for repairs so he has to look for money to complete their work for them before full payment is made.
Alex is asking for a loan of US $ 1,000 dollars to enable him buy more materials such as car plates for repairing car bodies, manufacture ovens, buy gas, electrodes for welding.

loans.use: Alex is asking for a loan of US $ 1,000 dollars to enable him buy more materials such as car plates for repairing car bodies, manufacture ovens, buy gas, electrodes for welding.

loans.name: Rosemary

texts.en:
Mrs. Rosemary E. is 35 years old, lives in Benin City, and is married with 4 children.

She is requesting a loan of $450 to buy more books to sell. The loan will go a long way to improve her business. She is an LAPO member.

loans.use: Buy more books to sell.

loans.name: Helen

texts.en:
Mrs. Helen A. is a 52-year-old widow with 10 children, who lives in Benin City. She makes and sells bean cakes (Akara).

She is seeking a loan of $875 to buy more beans for preparing bean cakes (Akara). She learned this business from her mother. She has been a LAPO member for 4 years

loans.use: Buy more supplies to make Akara to sell

loans.name: Nana

texts.en:
Nana, 36, owns a barber shop in his home community. He is also a father of a 6-year-old and 4 year-old. He has been in business for six years. Over those six years, he’s become very popular; as a result, his store expanded rapidly. He now has two employees and boasts steady business.

Eventually, Nana would like to open more shops and hire more employees around Kasoa, but first he needs a loan to replace some of his barbering equipment. The weather in Ghana is very humid, which makes things wear and rust pretty quickly. Nana hopes to purchase new shavers, lights, decorations, and a sterilizer (which will help maintain the shavers).

Nana is a member of the lending group, Faith. The group guarantees a loan through a group repayment pledge. Peer pressure and support provide the incentive to repay; if one person in the group defaults, the group members make up the payment amount.

loans.use: To purchase electric shaver, sterilizer, lights, and decorations

loans.name: Joy

texts.en:
A 49-year-old widow with 4 chilren, Mrs. Joy O. lives in Benin City. She deals with ladies' used clothes. She worked with someone for a year to learn the business, and then started her own business in 1995.

She is soliciting a loan of $1200 to buy more used ladies' clothing to sell. She is a client of LAPO. She thanks you.

loans.use: Buy more used ladies' clothes to sell

loans.name: Kate

texts.en:
Mrs. Kate O. sells plastic and rubber household items. She started the business in 2000.

She is 37 years old, lives in Benin City, and is married with 6 children. She has been a client of LAPO for 2 years.

She is requesting a loan to buy more plastic and rubber household items to sell.

loans.use: Buy more plastic and rubber household items to sell

loans.name: Subgroup E Of Group Sungura

texts.en:
Athumani, age 29, lives with his wife and 7-year-old daughter. His business involves selling small packets of powdered soap from door to door, which he began doing in 2005. Before this soap business, he sold peanuts and cassava. He now sells soap from 7am to 10am, after which he sells it outside their house until evening. He buys a 50 kg bag of soap at about $11 and decants it into smaller packets to sell. One 50 kg bag gives him a profit of around $6. Athumani also does part-time work making small house repairs and construction.

Athumani is the leader of Subgroup E for group Sungura (Swahili for “Rabbit”), which totals 31 members. He will be sharing this loan with his subgroup members: Emmanuel M. (bicycle repair shop), Shababani Y. (general store), Godfrey F. (market seller), Gloria G. (market seller), and Kefline L. (market seller). Athumani knows each of his subgroup members and their businesses personally since they all live and work in the same neighborhood. Within the last few months, they were able to pay back their 3rd loan from Tujijenge Tanzania successfully.

With this new loan, Athumani wishes to buy more sacks of powdered soap. He also hopes to eventually expand his business to begin selling candy and biscuits.

In the picture, Athumani is wearing the red cap.

loans.use: To buy powdered soap

loans.name: Christian Rural

texts.en:
Alex K. Gurah is a welder at Moree junction near cape coast. He has his own shop. He is also married with four children ages 12, 8, 6 and 2 years respectively. The wife is a trader and she sells foodstuffs. Alex also manufactures baking ovens, coalpot (traditional stove used for cooking here in Ghana). He has lots of customers. In addition to this, Alex also sells car plates. At Alex shop, lots of car has been parked there awaiting body works (maintenance). He also has three apprentices understudying him.
One major challenge that Alex faces is that most of his customers do not make full payment when they bring their cars to him for repairs so he has to look for money to complete their work for them before full payment is made.
Alex is asking for a loan of US $ 1,000 dollars to enable him buy more materials such as car plates for repairing car bodies, manufacture ovens, buy gas, electrodes for welding.

loans.use: James is therefore asking for a loan of US $ 800 dollars to enable him fill his store with more radiators, fans for all kinds of cars, waterholes, clips and bearing.

loans.name: Khursheda

texts.en: Khursheda is a mother of 4 children, she has friendly family and her husband and her children help her with her business. She became client of Microinvest in 2003. Her first loan was about 500 somoni and she spent it on expanding her inventory. Her businesses is very successful, which she attributes to her excellent customer service – she is quick, friendly and polite and always has a smile on her face. She also sells a wide range of shoes so that her customers can usually find what they are looking for. She is now applying for this loan from Microinvest in order to further expand her successful business.

loans.use: Business expansion

loans.name: Patience

texts.en:
Mrs. Patience O., is 45 years old, has 7 children, and is married to Mr. O.. The family lives in Benin City.

In 1992, Mrs. O. started her business selling slightly used clothes. She is asking for a loan of $875 to buy more slightly used clothes to sell.

loans.use: Buy a bale of used clothes to sell

loans.name: Clara

texts.en:
Mrs. Clara M. operates a bar where she sells drinks. She worked with her husband for a year to learn the business.

She is 28 years old, married, and lives in Benin City. She has been a client of LAPO for 3 years.

Mrs. M. requests a loan of $1200 so she can buy more drinks and pepper soup ingredients. This will help her serve her customers better. The loan will go a long way to help her increase her business.

loans.use: Buy ingredients for pepper soup and drinks to sell

loans.name: Caroline

texts.en:
Mrs. Caroline I. operates a bar where she sells pepper soup and drinks. She worked with someone else for 8 months to learn the business, and then established her own business in 2003. Mrs. I. is 43 years old, married with 4 children, and she lives in Benin City.

She requests a loan to buy more drinks to increase her business. She has been a client of LAPO for 3 years.

loans.use: Buy more drinks to sell

loans.name: Helen

texts.en:
Mrs. Helen O., a 48-year-old woman, lives in Benin City, is married and has a child. She has a store where she sells provisions, including rice and drinks. She worked for someone else for a year and 6 months to learn this business, and then opened her own store in 2000.

She requests a loan of $875 to buy provisions, including and drinks to sell. She thanks you.

loans.use: Buy provisions, including rice and drinks to sell

loans.name: Jacob

texts.en:
Jacob, 47, owns a secondhand sportswear stand in the market at Kasoa. He is requesting a loan in order to make a deposit for a box of secondhand clothing. Those who are able to make deposits on the clothing are able to choose from a better selection, thus making higher profits when selling.

With the extra profit, Jacob will help pay for the education fees of his three children. One is in junior high, another is training to become a teacher, and the oldest is studying at the university. Jacob also owns a palm oil plantation that he hopes to expand as well. In the future, Jacob hopes to shift from selling individual pieces of used sportswear to becoming a wholesaler.

Jacob is a member of the lending group, Voice of God. The group guarantees a loan through a group repayment pledge. Peer pressure and support provide the incentive to repay; if one person in the group defaults, the group members make up the payment amount.

loans.use: To purchase secondhand sportswear

loans.name: Esther

texts.en: Mrs. Esther O. is 50 years old; she is married with 10 children, and lives in Benin City.  She operates a mini-supermarket and she is asking for a loan of $875 to buy more food, wine and fruit juice for sale.  She is a LAPO member.  She learned this business from her mother and started her own business in 2006.

loans.use: To buy more food, wine and fruit juice for sale

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en: Mrs. Margaret E. is 40 years old.  She is married with 5 children, and lives in Benin City.  She sells plywood.  She trained in business for a year and established her own business in 1999.  She is requesting a loan to enable her to buy more plywood for sale.  She has been a LAPO member for 4 years.

loans.use: To buy more wood for sale

loans.name: Asimawu

texts.en:
Asimawu was attending secretarial professional school, but withdrew from the school when she had her first child in order to provide care and support. Now she sells handbags and cloth to shops in the Accra market. She also hawks (selling by walking with her products) her products when she has the time.

With her profits, Asimawu hopes to provide the highest education possible for her two children. She is currently single and lives with her parents. Her mother helps her take care of her children. Her father is too old to support the family, so they are all trying to earn enough money to take care of each other.

Asimawu is a member of the lending group, Vision. The group guarantees a loan through a group repayment pledge. Peer pressure and support provide the incentive to repay; if one person in the group defaults, the group members make up the payment amount.

loans.use: To purchase handbags and cloth

loans.name: Makhluga

texts.en: Ms. Makhluga S. is a 29 year old single woman who lives in a village called Yenikand, which is situated in the Salyan region of Azerbaijan with her father (pictured). She first started her farming business seven years ago. She is now applying for this $1200 loan in order to buy pesticides to help protect her crops and increase her income.

loans.use: to buy pesticides

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Continue buying materials such as beads and stones that she uses to make jewelry.

loans.name: Farakhim

texts.en: Mr. Farakhim A. is a 22 year old single man, living in the Salyan region of Azerbaijan. He first started his grocery store two years ago and it has been growing ever since. He is now requesting a loan of $1200 so that he can expand his inventory in order to meet customer demand.

loans.use: to buy goods

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase new products.

loans.name: Philomina

texts.en: Mrs. Philomina M. is 40 years old. She is married and has 5 children. She sells clothes and has been in business since 1990. She is in need of a loan of $875 to enable her to buy more clothes for sale.

loans.use: To buy more clothes for sale

loans.name: Faith

texts.en: Mrs. Faith I. is a 28-year-old woman who is married with 3 children and lives in Benin city.  She sells yams, and is seeking a loan to enable her to buy more yams for sale.  This is a business she started in 2006.  She thanks you.

loans.use: To buy more Yams for sale

loans.name: Adesuwa

texts.en: Miss. Adesuwa A. is 28 years old.  She is single and lives in Benin City.  She sells beauty products.  She trained in the business for 6 months and started her own in 2002.  She is requesting a loan to buy more stock for sale.  She is a LAPO member.

loans.use: To buy more products for sale

loans.name: Christian Rural

texts.en:
Florence Adu – Gyamfi sells provisions (milk, milo, oaths, rice, biscuits, minerals, mineral water etc). She is married with three children ages 16, 12 and 8 years respectively. Her husband is a steel bender and his income is low. To help in the family finances, Florence works very hard. In addition to the provisions that she sells, she is also a seamstress and sows dresses for people whiles at her provision store.
Some of the challenges that she faces is that her hand sewing machine is old so she needs a new hand sewing machine to help her sow dresses more quickly for people since the old one that she is using gives her problems when sowing. Her stock is also going down because now, she has to make an advance payment before she receives supplies from her suppliers.
She is therefore asking for a loan of US $ 1,000 dollars to enable her make advance payment to her suppliers so that they can supply provisions such as milk, milo, nido, biscuits, sardines, mineral water, crates of minerals etc. and also, to purchase a new hand sewing machine. She intends paying the loan back within seven months.

loans.use: To buy a new hand sewing machine, fill the shop with provisions such as milk, milo, minerals, soap, mineral water etc.

loans.name: Philomina

texts.en: Mrs. Philomina O. is 40 years old. She is married and has 4 children. She lives in Benin City and has a restaurant. She has 6 years of experience in business. She is in need of a loan of $1200 to enable her to buy more drinks and foodstuffs. This, she said, will help her serve her customers better. She thanks you.

loans.use: To buy more foodstuffs and drinks for sale

loans.name: Stella

texts.en: Mrs. Stella O. is 38 years old of age.  She lives in Benin City and is married with 6 children.  She sells fabric and rubber slippers. She trained in her business for 6 months and started her own in 2002.  She is requesting a loan to buy more fabric and slippers for sale.  She is a LAPO member.

loans.use: To buy more fabric and slippers for sale

loans.name: Comfort

texts.en: Mrs. Comfort I. is 45 years old, married, and has 3 children.  She lives in Benin City.  She sells food and she is seeking a loan of $400 to enable her to buy more food for sale.  She trained in this business with her mother and started her own in 2001.  She thanks you.

loans.use: To buy more food for sale

loans.name: Philomina

texts.en: Mrs. Philomina O. is 40 years old and married with 5 children. She lives in Benin City and sells palm oil, and she is requesting a loan of $450 to buy more oil for sale. She has been in business since 2004.

loans.use: To buy more palm oil for sale

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en: Miss Sarah A., a 24-year-old, lives in Benin City and has a business center where she sells handsets, lines, and recharge cards, and allows customers to make phone calls.  She trained in this business for a year and established her own in 2004.  She is requesting a loan to enable her to buy more handsets, lines and recharge card for sale. She thanks you.

loans.use: To buy more handsets, lines and recharge cards for sale.

loans.name: Amelia

texts.en:
Amelia, 35, took her first loan for her porridge business. She repaid the loan with no problem, but decided that a secondhand clothing business would be more profitable. She took her capital and started selling bags, shoes and clothes at the Fatamantu market in Accra. She’s been there for two years now and would like to expand her business with more stock. With the loan, her profits are expected to raise approximately $30 a week.

Amelia currently lives with her 12-year-old and 7-year-old in a rental house with many other families. She hopes to build a house for just her family when she has enough money.

Amelia is a member of the lending group, Yaweh. The group guarantees a loan through a group repayment pledge. Peer pressure and support provide the incentive to repay; if one person in the group defaults, the group members make up the payment amount. The photo shows Amelia (center left) with some members of her lending group.

loans.use: To purchase secondhand clothing

loans.name: Christiana

texts.en: Mrs. Christiana E. is a dealer in pure water and table water. She started her business in 1996 and seeks a loan to enable her to buy more pure water and table water for sale. With the funds, she will also buy a deep-freeze for cooling the water. She is 47 years old, married with 7 children, and lives in Benin City with her family. She has been in LAPO for 6 years.

loans.use: To buy more pure water and buy a deep-freeze for cooling water.

loans.name: Aminah

texts.en: Aminah is 42 years old and the mother of a 7-year-old daughter. Together with her husband, S., she sells snacks and day-to-day necessities in her small shop . She usually earns $10 per day. She is hoping to receive this loan to buy some goods to fill her shop and expand her business. She depends on this business because it's the only source of income they have. She is willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: To buy more goods to fill her shop

loans.name: Jane

texts.en: Mrs. Jane I. is 45 years old, married, and has 3 children.  She lives in Benin City and operates a store where she sells clothing and products for babies.  She is requesting a loan to enable her to buy more stock for sale.  She trained in her business for a year and six months, and started up in 2002. She is a dedicated member of LAPO.

loans.use: To buy more baby things for sale

loans.name: Georgina

texts.en:
Georgina, 46, owns a yam stand at the Kantamento market in Kasoa and a fresh foods store in front of her home. When she is at the market, her children take care of the store in front of her house. Georgina has four children. The two younger ones are still in school. She plans to use her profits to support them through their education.

Yam is a root used in many traditional Ghanaian dishes. You are likely to have it daily in Ghana, whether it is in fou-fou, yam balls, palava dishes, or just plain yams. The loan will allow Georgina to purchase more yams for both her store in the market and the store in front of her house. Eventually Georgina would like to expand the space she has at the market, but it is relatively expensive, with each stall costing approximately $325.

Georgina is a member of the lending group, Faith. The group guarantees a loan through a group repayment pledge. Peer pressure and support provide the incentive to repay; if one person in the group defaults, the group members make up the payment amount.

loans.use: To expand her business by purchasing yams

loans.name: Christopher Agbon

texts.en: Mr. Christopher Agbon A., 38 years old, is married and has a child.  He lives in Benin City, and has a store where he sells plastic containers and other plastic products.  He is requesting a loan to buy more stock for sale.  He learnt his business from his mother and started his own in 1998.  He thanks you.

loans.use: To buy more plastic products for sale

loans.name: Adesuwa

texts.en: Mrs. Adesuwa E., 40 years old, is married and has six children.  She lives in Benin City.  She deals in cosmetics; she trained in this business for 1 year and 6 months, and started up in 2002.  She is requesting a loan of $450 to enable her to buy more cosmetics for sale.  She has been working with LAPO for 2 years.

loans.use: To buy more cosmetics for sale

loans.name: Sani

texts.en: Sani is 45 years old and is the mother of a child aged 15. Previously she had a small shop where she sold snacks etc. but she had to close it due to lack of capital. After joining MBK, she started a new business together with her husband, S., selling meatballs. She is requesting a loan that she can use for this new business as capital and make it sustainable. She is willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: To use as capital for their meatball business

loans.name: Christian Rural

texts.en:
At Yamoransa station near cape coast is a well known chop bar operator Madam Grace Cramson. She is a chop bar operator and has a lots of customers. Her customers are drivers, passengers who use the Accra – Cape Coast highway and people in and around yamoransa area. She is married and has three children aged 22, 12 and 7 years. Her husband is a driver and he has his own vehicle. Madam Cramson is a hardworking woman. She has a drinking spot too. To help the finances of her family, she also sells all kinds of assorted drinks eg. Minerals, some locally made drinks such as kasapreko, oprim quansah, schnapps etc.
One challenge that Madam Cramson faces is that she always runs out of drinks because she have to make an advance payment before she receives supply from her suppliers such as coca cola company of Ghana and the Ghana Breweries.
She is therefore asking for a loan of US $ 1,000 dollars to enable her buy more crates of minerals (malta Guinness, coca cola, fanta, sprite etc) to fill her drinking spot attached to her chop bar.

loans.use: To buy more crates of minerals (malta Guinness, coca cola, fanta, sprite etc) to fill her drinking spot attached to her chop bar.

loans.name: Iim

texts.en: Iim is 46 years old and lives only with her husband since her children have married and live separately. She sells clothes on credit. She usually earns US$ 30 profit per month and it's just enough to cover their daily needs. She is requesting a loan of IDR 900,000 (US$ 100)  to expand her business and is willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: To expand her business selling clothing

loans.name: Nyai

texts.en: Nyai is 40 years old and mother of a child aged 8. She sells clothes on credit and usually goes around to various places to get more customers. She usually earns $30 per month. Her husband, I., sells vegetables in the market and earns $20 per week. Nyai is requesting a loan of US$ 100 (about IDR 900,000) to expand her business by buying more goods for resale and also to expand her husband's business. She is willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: To buy more clothes for resale

loans.name: Ebah

texts.en: Ebah is 32 years old and is the mother of a 9-year-old daughter. Since joining MBK, she sells veils on credit by going to various places. She can earn $2 per day. Her husband, S., sells vegetables in the market. Ebah is requesting a loan in the amount of US$ 75 to buy more goods for her to sell and also to expand her husband's business. She is willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: To buy more goods and also expand her husband's business

loans.name: Yatinah

texts.en: Yatinah is 35 years old and is mother of a child aged 10. Selling flavoured ice (popsicles) was her business before joining MBK. She usually earns $2 per day, but in the summer she can earn up to $4 per day. Her husband, U., sells vegetables in Tangerang, Banten, Indonesia and earns $20 per week. Yatinah needs a loan of US$ 100 (about IDR 900,000) to expand her business so she can sell various flavours such as fruit-flavoured ices or milk flavoured pops and also to expand her husband's business. She is willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: To expand her own and her husband's business

loans.name: Neng

texts.en: Neng N. is 30 years old and is mother of a 9-year-old son. Since she joined MBK, she has been selling some foods, snacks, household goods and cigarettes in her small shop. She can gross US$ 30 per day. Her husband, Obih, is a farmer and usually sells his plants at the market. He can earn US$ 20 per week. Neng is requesting a loan of US$ 100 (about IDR 900,000) to buy more goods for her shop. She is wiling to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: To buy more goods for her shop

loans.name: Tati

texts.en: Tati is a 28-year-old married woman. She has a small shop where she sells snacks, noodles, household goods, and sometimes she also sells meatballs. She can earn US$ 25 or $3 profit per day. Her husband, S., is a  pedicab driver who earns a small income. Tati is requesting a loan of US$ 125 (about IDR 1,000,000) to buy more goods for her shop and hopes that that way, she can earn more income. She is willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: To buy more goods to sell in her shop

loans.name: Ismawati

texts.en: Ismawati is 24 years old and the mother of a child aged 3. She has been running her business selling snacks, household goods, and cigarettes in her small shop. She usually earns $10 per day whereas her husband, A., is a laborer at the market who earns a small income. Ismawati is requesting a loan to buy more goods to fill her shop and hopes that, with more inventory, she can contribute more toward her family's income. She is willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: To buy more goods for her shop

loans.name: Nyai

texts.en: Nyai is 31 years old and is the mother of a child aged 11. Since joining MBK two years ago, she has been selling some cakes and snacks. Sometimes she sells an Indonesian salad called 'gado - gado'. She usually earns $10 per day. Her husband, S., usually earns some money by taking people to various places on his motorcycle. Nyai is requesting a loan to produce various cakes and buy more goods to fill her food stall.  She is willing repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: To produce more various food

loans.name: Aminah

texts.en: Aminah is a 45-year-old married woman. She has a small stall where she sells some foods: cakes and fried snacks. She also sells vegetables, going to various places to find customers. She can earn $10 per day and it's just enough to cover their daily needs. She is a member of MBK and is requesting a loan of US$ 100 to buy more goods to sell. She is willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: To buy more goods for resale

loans.name: Susilawati

texts.en: Susilawati, 23 years old, is mother of a child aged 5. She has been running her business selling cosmetics on credit. She usually goes around to various places to sell them. She usually earns $10 per week and is requesting a loan of US$ 75 to expand her business, buy more goods to sell. Her husband, A., is a driver who earns a small income. Susilawati is willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: To buy more cosmetics for resale

loans.name: Teti

texts.en: Teti is 34 years old and mother of a child aged 12. She has a small shop where she sells snacks, household goods, kerosene, etc. She usually earns about $6 per day. Her husband, Jaja, is a driver who earns $15 per week. Teti is a member of MBK and is requesting this $75 loan to buy more goods to fill her shop. She is willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: To buy more goods to fill her shop

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase of produce such as garlic, lemons, and onions

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more merchandise such as household items and beds.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase more goods for her store

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy more merchandise for a larger profit margin.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase of more cosmetic merchandise

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase of clothing and accessories for the end of the year

loans.name: Mohammed

texts.en:
Mohammed M. was born in the northern region of Ghana. He moved south, to Accra, with his wife when he realized that there is a market for goods delivered from the northern region. Along with his brother, Mohammed buys large sacks of peanuts and corn from Tamale. Then he brings the goods to Accra to sell to vendors around the city or to keep in a store at the Accra timber market.

Since moving to Accra, Mohammed proudly has become a father of 3 children. Mohammed is currently completing the construction of the house where they are living. His next and final project is to add electricity for lights in the house. Because of the construction, Mohammed does not have the capital to buy as many sacks of peanuts, corn, and Guinea corn as he hopes. The trip to Tamale takes a full day. If Mohammed receives the loan, he would be able to purchase more sacks so that he does not have to make extra trips just because he does not have the capital.

Mohammed is a leader of the lending group, Trust. The group guarantees a loan through a group repayment pledge. Peer pressure and support provide the incentive to repay; if one person in the group defaults, the group members make up the payment amount.

loans.use: To purchase 12 to 15 sacks of peanuts, corn, and Guinea corn.

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en:
Evelyn D., 38, hawks tie and dye cloth. She has been very successful in her business, but it comes with a costs to her health. Hawkers walk around under the scorching Ghanaian sun, selling what they carry and balance on their heads. Evelyn expresses frequent fevers from being outdoors for such long periods of time. It causes her to be exposed to diseases and viruses carried by mosquitoes, including malaria.

Once she earns enough money, she will find an alternative to hawking. However, her first priority is taking care of her 10-year-old son.

Evelyn is a member of the lending group, Hope. The group guarantees a loan through a group repayment pledge. Peer pressure and support provide the incentive to repay; if one person in the group defaults, the group members make up the payment amount.

loans.use: To purchase tie and dye cloth

loans.name: Akwasi

texts.en:
Akwasi, 30, sells clothing and cell phone units from a wooden structure on the roadside. He has great relationship with his customers. Although his business is strong, the government may demolish his shop in order to build a highway. If that is the case, he plans to move into a metal container at a nearby location.

Akwasi is optimistic about the move. He believes that his new location will generate more profits. First, he needs to save more money, and the loan will help him do so. He hopes to expand his stock by purchasing more pairs of jeans. This will increase his profits which will be used for his new store as well as taking care of his four-year-old son.

Akwasi is a member of the lending group, Hope. This group guarantees the loan through a group repayment pledge. Peer pressure and support provide the incentive to repay; if one person in the group defaults, the group members make up the payment amount.

loans.use: To expand his business by purchasing jeans.

loans.name: Albertina

texts.es:
Albertina works tirelessly everyday with the sole purpose of providing a better future for her beloved family. She has always struggled to shape a brighter future for herself. For this reason, at a young age, she dedicated herself to agriculture, a domain which she learned thanks to the guidance of her parents. She cultivates and sells bananas and guanabanas. She accomplishes her daily efforts with the help of her dear husband, who is a team player, and with whom Albertina has vowed to offer a good education to her adored children. Thanks to their great vitality and optimism, they have been able to overcome many obstacles. Albertina will keep working because she wants to prosper and raise the family’s standard of living. For these reasons, she wants to produce more crops on her small farm with the aim of boosting sales. Let’s help her so that she may continue to complete her work without difficulties.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer.

Albertina, trabaja incansablemente día a día con el único propósito de brindarle un mejor futuro a su amada familia. Siempre ha laborado para forjarse un futuro mejor y es por esa razón que desde muy joven se dedica a la agricultura, actividad que aprendió gracias a la instrucción de sus padres desde muy pequeña en el seno de su hogar, ella cultiva y comercializa guanábanas y plátanos.Su desempeño diario lo realiza en compañía de su querido esposo, con una mentalidad de trabajo en equipo muy fuerte, y con quien se ha propuesto brindarle una buena educación a sus queridos hijos. Gracias al ánimo y optimismo han sobrellevado situaciones difíciles. Albertina seguirá trabajando porque quiere prosperar y elevar el nivel de vida de su familia y por estos deseos es que quiere producir mayor cantidad de productos en su chacra con el fin de incrementar sus ventas. Ayudémosla para que siga realizando su labor sin dificultades.

loans.use: Increase capital to be able to produce a greater amount of crops

loans.name: Vilma Inés

texts.es:
Vilma is a very friendly, affable, and hardworking woman, mother to two young children. Although in her family there have been difficult economic obstacles to overcome, she has decided to work hard and diligently to get ahead along with her family. She owns a little shop where she sells various products of basic needs and spends most of her time during the days of the week. Because of her friendly nature and dedication, she has gained great satisfaction through her humble work and her next goal is to increase the square footage of her little shop in order to increase the number of products she offers and thus improve her services, increase clientele, and earn more profit to fix her bamboo house. To make her dreams come true, she asks for a loan as investment capital. We can be an important part of the expansion of this business.

Translated from Spanish by Lizella West, Kiva Volunteer.

Doña Vilma, es una mujer muy amigable, afable y laboriosa, es madre de dos pequeños niños, y aunque en su familia haya circunstancias económicas muy difíciles por afrontar, ella ha decidido esforzarse y trabajar con mayor diligencia para progresar junto a su familia; ella cuenta con una pequeña bodega en el que vende diversos productos de primera necesidad y permanece la mayor parte de su tiempo durante todos los días de la semana. A causa de su carácter tan amigable y dedicado ha podido recoger muchas satisfacciones a través de esta humilde labor y ahora su meta próxima es ampliar la infraestructura de su pequeño puesto de trabajo con el deseo de aumentar la pluralidad de productos que brinda, a fin de mejorar sus servicios e incrementar la cantidad de clientes para obtener mayores ingresos económicos que le permitan mejorar su casa que esta construida con bambú.Y para concretar este anhelo solicita un préstamo de dinero que utilizará como capital de inversión. Vosotros podemos ser parte importante del crecimiento de este negocio.

loans.use: Expansion of small shop to offer a larger selection of products with better cleanliness and security.

loans.name: Ana María

texts.es:
Ana is very enterprising and friendly. She has dedicated herself to the preparation and selling of food for many years and is well known for her exquisite cooking along with the courtesy and friendly customer service that characterize her business. This position along with her husband's hardwork has allowed them to open a small store in their home. She is the mother of two small children whom she is very dedicated to and with love and affection is raising them to have good values. Her strength and good spirits have made her well known throughout her neighborhood and every day her clientele increases in her two small businesses; this significant growth is a reflection of her love of cooking and work. However, being an enterprising woman, she wishes to expand into other markets such as cosmetics in order to increase her sources of income and continue building her house. She requests a loan to purchase new products for her businesses. Let us support Ana in realizing her wishes.

Translated from Spanish by Lizella West, Kiva volunteer.

Doña Ana, es una mujer emprendedora y amable, se dedica a la preparación y venta de comida desde hace muchos años y por la que es muy conocida debido a su excelente sazón y a la gran cortesía y amabilidad que la caracterizan. Este desempeño le ha permitido junto al esfuerzo de su esposo poder aperturar una pequeña bodega en las instalaciones de su hogar.Ella es madre de dos pequeños niños a los que se ha dedicado y con amor y sumo afecto les inculca buenos valores. Su gran fortaleza y ánimo la han hecho sumamente conocida en su localidad y cada vez acoge mayor cantidad de clientes en sus dos pequeños negocios, este significativo crecimiento es producto de su amor por la cocina y el trabajo. Sin embargo como mujer emprendedora, ella desea incursionar también en otros ámbitos del mercado como el de los cosméticos, con el propósito de contar con más fuentes de ingresos en su hogar para continuar con la construcción de su casita. Solicita un préstamo para invertir este capital exclusivamente en la compra de productos para sus actividades actuales. Solidaricémonos con Ana para poder hacer realidad su anhelada labor.

loans.use: Increase in capital to expand the amount of products in two small businesses.

loans.name: Víctor Luis

texts.es:
Victor works hard to cultivate his products such as bananas and avocados. He sells them in the market where they are always in high demand due to their good quality. He began this work because he realized the great business opportunity and economic need in his city, where there was not much work nor many opportunities. His works fills him with great optimism and allows him to help his beloved children. His goal is to improve the quality of his agricultural products even more and grow his business. He is requesting a loan to buy greater quantities of seeds and fertilizer, better meeting the demands of his customers who wait for him every Saturday at the market. Let's help Victor as he works hard to improve the quality of life for his family.

Encontramos a Víctor trabajando impetuosamente en el cultivo de deliciosos y apetecibles productos como; el plátano y la palta, productos que posteriormente son comercializados en el mercado siendo muy solicitados por toda la población y comerciantes debido a su calidad y buen sabor. Él se dedica a esta actividad por la inmensa oportunidad de negocio que ha observado y por la necesidad económica que existe en su ciudad de residencia debido a la falta de trabajo y oportunidades, por lo que con gran amor se desempeña en sus actividades agrícolas, ya que este trabajo lo llena de optimismo y además le permite transmitir su apoyo a sus queridos hijos.Él es aún un gran sostén económico en su hogar y por esta razón trabaja incansablemente con un solo objetivo, ofrecerle estudios superiores a sus cuatro queridos hijos. El deseo de este virtuoso padre es mejorar la calidad de sus productos agrícolas, para lo cual necesita comprar mayor cantidad de abonos y semillas a fin de seguir satisfaciendo los paladares de sus clientes que esperan ansiosos cada sábado de feria probar el excelente sabor de sus productos.Para cumplir sus objetivos solicita un préstamo. Ayudemos a Víctor a continuar con su noble tarea por el bienestar de su amada familia.

Translated by Kiva volunteer, Emily Charnes

loans.use: TO PURCHASE GREATER QUANTITIES OF SEEDS AND FERTILIZERS TO IMPROVE THE QUALITY OF HIS PRODUCTS AND GROW HIS BUSINESS.

loans.name: Amelia

texts.es:
Amelia and her husband work cultivating and selling products such as coffee and citrus fruits, items very much in demand in their city. With this work they have been able to cover the basic household needs. Amelia begins working very early in the morning, fertilizing the crops and then returning to run her small shop where she sells every day necessities and groceries. The shop was set up with a lot of hard work to help sustain them during the harvest of their products. Her goal is to grow the business and begin distributing products in the city of Pichanaki, and in the different markets around the country, generating more income to prepare for their children's education. She is requesting a loan to help them meet their goals. Let's contribute and help this dedicated mother provide a better future for her children.

Amelia, es una madre amorosa de un pequeño niño; desde que formó su familia se dedica en compañía de su esposo a la producción y comercialización de café y productos cítricos, productos muy cotizados de su ciudad, con el que ha podido cubrir las necesidades básicas de su hogar.
