He is asking for a loan of US $800 to enable him to renovate his shop, buy more fridges and fridge motors from his suppliers, and to buy air conditioner gas.

loans.use: To renovate his shop, buy more fridges and fridge motors from his suppliers, and buy air conditioner gas.

loans.name: Onih

texts.en:
Onih is 23 years old and a mother of one child, aged 1. Together with her husband M., they run a small shop. Their shop sells snacks, cigarettes and household goods among other items. They usually earn $8 per day.

Onih is a member of MBK. She requests IDR 500,000 ($75 USD) to purchase goods to fill her shop. She is willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: To buy more goods to fill her shop

loans.name: Krista

texts.en:
Krista is 38 years old and a mother of one son, aged 12. Krista and her husband J. sell household goods such as cooking oil, snacks, rice and eggs. They usually earn $30 per day in profit. This small shop is their only source of income to support their family's needs.

Krista is a member of MBK. She is requesting IDR 1,000,000 ($125 USD) to buy more goods to fill her shop. She is willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: To buy more goods for her shop

loans.name: Philip

texts.en:
At Moree Junction near Cape Coast is a well-known carpentry shop called “Talented Creative Furniture.” The owner of this business is Mr. Philip Q. who makes all kinds of furniture for both private and public organizations, schools, and his individual clients. Philip has eleven apprentices studying under him. He is 36 years of age and married with three children ages 11, 9, and 5 years. His wife is a trader who sells provisions such as milk, milo, and soap.

He is also a member of a lending group called “Emmanuel Traders Group.” The members of this group have known each other for many years, and they provide support for each other as they are all located at the same place – Yamoransa – on the Accra Highway.

One challenge Philip faces is that organizations and individuals always ask him to make furniture for them, but because of the high cost of wood, foams, leathers and the materials used, he sometimes loses his customers to his competitors because they have been able to secure loans from some financial organizations. As a result, Philip needs a loan of US $1,100 to purchase wood, foams, leathers, nails and the material used to manufacture the furniture in order to meet the demands of his customers.

loans.use: To purchase wood, foams, leathers, nails and the material used to manufacture furniture in order to meet the demands of his customers.

loans.name: Ina

texts.en:
Ina is 25 years old and a mother of one child, aged 5. She sells clothes on credit. She has been running her business for quite a long time. She can earn a profit of $2.50 per day. Her husband, D., is a motorcycle driver who has no regular income.

Ina is a member of MBK. She is requesting IDR 500,000 ($75 USD) to expand her business and generate more income. She is willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: To buy various types of clothes

loans.name: Alex

texts.en:
Alex K. G. is a welder at Moree Junction near Cape Coast. He has his own shop. He is also married with four children ages 12, 8, 6 and 2 years respectively. His wife is a trader, and she sells foodstuffs. Alex also manufactures baking ovens and coalpot (traditional stove used for cooking here in Ghana). He has lots of customers. In addition to this, Alex also sells car plates. At Alex's shop, lots of cars have been parked awaiting body works (maintenance). He also has three apprentices working under him.

One major challenge that Alex faces is that most of his customers do not make full payment when they bring their cars to him for repairs, so he has to look for money to complete their work for them before full payment is made.

Alex is asking for a loan of US $1,000 to enable him to buy more car plates for repairing car bodies, materials to manufacture ovens, gas, and electrodes for welding.

loans.use: To buy more car plates for repairing car bodies, materials to manufacture ovens, gas, and electrodes for welding.

loans.name: James

texts.en:
James N. is a radiator repairer at Moree Junction near Cape Coast. He repairs radiators and fans and sells water holes for all kinds of cars. He also has his own shop. He is a well-known radiator repairer. He is married with four children ages 18, 14, 10 and 8 respectively. His wife is a trader who sells kenkey, a typical Ghanaian food. James is a hardworking man. In addition to the repairs, he also sells clips and car bearings.

One major challenge that James faces is that he has run out of stock of radiators, fans, and waterholes because his suppliers now demand advance payment before supply is made to him.

James is therefore asking for a loan of US $800 to enable him to fill his store with more radiators, fans for all kinds of cars, waterholes, clips and bearings. He intends to pay the loan back within seven months.

loans.use: To fill his store with more radiators, fans for all kinds of cars, waterholes, clips and bearings.

loans.name: Uwar

texts.en:
Uwar is 37 years old and a mother of one child, aged 11. Her business is selling clothes on credit. Uwar has been running her business for quite a long time. She usually earns $3 per day. Her husband, S., is a farmer who palnts corn crops.

Uwar is a member of MBK. She requests IDR 500,000 ($75 USD) to expand her business and earn more income. She is willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: To buy more goods

loans.name: Florence Adu

texts.en:
Florence Adu – G. sells provisions (milk, milo, oats, rice, biscuits, minerals, and mineral water). She is married with three children ages 16, 12 and 8 years respectively. Her husband is a steel bender and his income is low. To help with the family finances, Florence works very hard. In addition to the provisions that she sells, she is also a seamstress and sews dresses for people while at her provision store.

One of the challenges that she faces is that her hand sewing machine is old, so she needs a new machine to help her sew dresses more quickly for people since the old one gives her problems when sewing. Her stock is also going down because she now has to make an advance payment before she receives supplies from her suppliers.

She is therefore asking for a loan of US $1,000 to enable her to make advance payment to her suppliers so that they can supply provisions such as milk, milo, nido, biscuits, sardines, mineral water, and crates of minerals; also, to purchase a new hand sewing machine. She intends to pay the loan back within seven months.

loans.use: To make advance payment to her suppliers for milk, milo, nido, biscuits, sardines, mineral water, and crates of minerals; also, to purchase a new hand sewing machine.

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
At Yamoransa station near Cape Coast is the well-known chop bar operator Madam Grace C.. She has lots of customers. Her customers are drivers, passengers who use the Accra – Cape Coast highway, and people in and around the Yamoransa area. She is married and has three children aged 22, 12 and 7 years. Her husband is a driver, and he has his own vehicle. Madam C. is a hardworking woman. She has a drinking spot, also. To help the finances of her family, she also sells all kinds of assorted drinks including minerals and some locally-made drinks such as kasapreko, oprim quansah, and schnapps.

One challenge that Madam C. faces is that she always runs out of drinks because she has to make an advance payment before she receives the shipment from her suppliers. Her suppliers include the Coca Cola company of Ghana and the Ghana Breweries.

She is therefore asking for a loan of US $1,000 to enable her to buy more crates of minerals (Malta Guinness, Coca Cola, Fanta, and Sprite) to fill her drinking spot attached to her chop bar.

loans.use: To buy more crates of minerals (Malta Guinness, Coca Cola, Fanta, and Sprite) to fill her drinking spot attached to her chop bar.

loans.name: Anita

texts.en:
Anita is 33 years old. She sells fried snacks by traveling through her village daily. She also helps her husband, S., to collect and sell waste and scrapt materials. Together they usually earn $15 per day. Hower, it is not enough to meet their family needs.

Anita is requesting this loan to expand her business capital so she can grow her business. She hopes this will increase her family's income. Anita is a member of MBK and willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: To expand her business capital

loans.name: Stephen

texts.en:
Mr. Stephen E. is an auto electrician at Moree Junction near Cape Coast. He was once married with two children ages 11 and 8 years, but he is currently divorced. Stephen has his own shop where he works on all kinds of car batteries. Stephen is a hardworking man. He also repairs all types of car starters and alternators. He is a well-known electrician at Moree Junction.

Stephen is asking for a loan of US $1,000 to purchase car starters, second-hand batteries, and car alternators to enable him to meet the demand of his customers.

loans.use: To purchase car starters, second-hand batteries, and car alternators to enable him to meet the demand of his customers.

loans.name: Ratna

texts.en:
Ratna is 30 years old and a mother of one child, aged 7. She sells clothes on credit and also sells a variety of vegetables in her stall. She can earn up to $5 per day. Her husband, S., works at a repair shop and earns $3 per day.

Ratna is requesting $75 to expand her and her husband's business. She is willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: To expand her business and her husband's business

loans.name: Isaac

texts.en:
Isaac B. is a carpenter who manufactures all kinds of furniture. He is married with five children. His wife is a trader who sells provisions such as milk, milo, and soaps. He works very hard to support his wife since her income is low. He also makes coffins and supplies organizations with all kinds of furniture.

Isaac is also a member of a lending group called “Emmanuel Traders Group.” The members of this group have known each other for many years, and they provide support for each other as they are all located at the same place – Yamoransa – on the Accra Highway.

One challenge that Isaac faces is that organizations and individuals always ask him to make furniture for them, but because of the high cost of wood, foams, leathers, and the materials used, he sometimes loses his customers to his competitors because they have been able to secure loans from financial organizations. As a result, Isaac needs a loan of US $1,100 to purchase wood, foams, leathers, nails, polish, tools, and the material used to manufacture furniture in order to meet the demands of his customers.

loans.use: To purchase wood, foams, leathers, nails, polish, tools, and the material used to manufacture furniture in order to meet the demands of his customers.

loans.name: Haniva

texts.en:
Haniva is 29 years old and a mother of one child, aged 7. Haniva sells clothes on credit. For her business, she goes door to door to reach customers. She can earn up to $5 per day. Her husband, J., is a driver who earns $2 per day.

Haniva needs a loan to expand her business. She would like to buy more types of clothes to sell. With her increased revenue she hopes to pay for her child's education. Haniva is a member of MBK and is willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: To expand her business

loans.name: Georgina

texts.en:
Georgina A. is a seamstress who sews all kinds of dresses. She is well-known for sewing “kaba,” a popular Ghanaian dress. She also sews children's and baby dresses, too. Georgina is married and has two children ages 3 and 1. Her husband is a driver who has his own car. Georgina works very hard. To support the finances of her family, she also sells cloth, materials used for sewing dresses, thread, and tape measures. She also sells mineral water.

She is a member of the lending group called “Emmanuel Traders Group,” and they provide support for each other. The members of the group have also known each other for a long time.

Georgina is asking for a loan of US $800 to enable her to buy an additional hand sewing machine and fill her store with cloths, materials, thread, needles, and tape measures.

loans.use: To buy an additional hand sewing machine and fill her store with cloths, materials, thread, needles and tape measures.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase more merchandise and a copy machine.

loans.name: Kerti

texts.id:
Made Kerti M. is a farmer whose living comes from land farming, however land condition could not support it, due to drought. That is why  Made Kerti is trying other avenues like cow farming, that he has calculated its feasibility from buying to selling. With this business, Made hopes he could provide  his family with a decent living, and provide schooling for his 4 small children. Calve's age are 3 months at a price of Rp 3,000,000-4,000,000/calf (Translator's note: 1US$ fluctuates between Rp9000-9500.00). He will raise the calves for 6 months, then sell it to pay for daily living expenses.
Translated from Bahasa Indonesia by Gwan Liong Ang, Kiva volunteer.
Made Kerti M. adalah seorang petani yang mengandalkan kehidupan keluarganya dari bercocok tanam, namun kondisi tanah yang kurang mendukung karena kekeringan maka Made Kerti mencoba usaha lain  dengan cara memelihara sapi yang tentunya telah diperhitungkan mulai dari pembelian sampai dengan penjualan. Dengan usaha ini Made berharap bisa menopang kehidupan keluarganya dengan memberikan kehidupan yang layak dan dapat menyekolahkan keempat anaknya yang masih kecil-kecil. Usia bibit sapi yaitu 3 bulan dengan harga 3.000.000 – 4.000.000 rupiah/ekor yang kemudian akan dipelihara sampai  usia 6 bulan yang kemudian akan dijual untuk kebutuhan hidup sehari-hari.

loans.use: To buy calves, feed and raising expensesuntuk membeli bibit sapi, bahan makanan dan biaya perawatan

loans.name: Thorn

texts.en:
Mrs. Thorn I. (age 52) has been widowed since 1997. She lives in a small village across the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers north of Phnom Penh. She shares her one-room house wI. three of her children, one son-in-law and one grandson. Though Thorn learned to weave from her mother many years ago, she’s been working at it commercially for only about seven or eight years. She has also taught her daughter, now age twenty-one, (see photo) who joined on a second loom. They both laughed that the daughter is now the better weaver because her eyes are better than her mother’s.

Thorn is requesting this, her third loan from MAXIMA, in the amount of $300. She will use the funds from the loan to buy materials for weaving. Prior to taking out a loan, Thorn worked on a barter basis wI. a local middleperson. The middleperson would advance her an amount of weaving thread. Out of that thread, Thorn would give back two finished pieces and get the profit only from one. She now makes more profit as the cost of the thread is less and the price she gets for the finished cloth is more – as long as she conducts all the transactions in cash.

In addition to weaving, Thorn also farms rice wI. her son-in-law. Her farm plot is five kilometers from her house so weaving productivity declines during planting and harvest seasons due to the demands of farm work and commuting. In addition to paying for family living costs and the fees for her one child who remains in school, she is saving money to buy a cow.

loans.use: To purchase silk and nylon thread and other materials for weaving

loans.name: Srun

texts.en:
Mr.Srun M. (age 64) married his wife, Luch Yom (age 57), in 1971. They live in a small village across the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers north of Phnom Penh. They share their one-room, stilt house with three of their eight children. The youngest child, a boy, studies in grade seven in the village school.

Like most everyone in rural Cambodia, Srun lives from the skills he’s learned and applied over the course of his life. On a 2,700 square meter plot of land he farms rice. In a good year, of every three kilos he harvests, he keeps two to feed his family and sells one. Interestingly, they expressed concern about the rice harvests. Apparently, demand for snake meat has increased dramatically as Cambodia’s growing economy creates an upper class that will pay more for exotic foods. Cobra meat sells for $10 or more per kilo in Phnom Penh currently. With fewer snakes as the natural predators, the population of mice has increased and mice are a pest that eats rice on the stalk. Srun said many farmers in the area do not know what to do.

Srun also currently has two cows and would like to buy another. He says he can make US$ 150 profit if he can raise one to maturity without illness. His wife weaves cloth of silk, cotton and nylon thread. She learned when she was eighteen from her older sister but only started again three years ago so she could teach one of her daughters.

They hope this loan will allow them to increase the family’s cash flow. Their primary goal is to keep the remaining son who studies, in school. The furthest any other children advanced was grade eleven.

loans.use: To purchase a cow, rice seed, fertilizer, and weaving materials

loans.name: Buluh Sari Group

texts.id:
In live, our society does not depend on our own individual, but as a social creature we depend on each other. By this principle, several people of Pangkung Buluh village, created a group by the name of: "Buluh Sari ”. This name was chosen since they live in the village of Pangkung Buluh. The Administration consisted of: Ni komang Darmini Chairperson, Ni Luh Wisadi secretary, and NiKomang Nariyati as cashier. This group activity goal is to increase group's living standard. Activities include: Savings & Borrowing; Volunteer work; and raising pigs in each member's house. In raising pigs this group so far are only doing it the traditional way, so that results are not maximal. To maximize results, the group has requested The Dinari Foundation help to work side by side with the group, provide training, besides loan to increase pig farming capital. Though Dinari's assistance the group plans to raise pigs of superior type and to buy Quality feed, so that results would be pigs at market's standard. Each group member needs capital of Rp1,100,000 (Translator's note: 1US$ fluctuates between Rp9000-9500); to buy 4 piglets at Rp250,000/each and feed of Rp100,000. After 5 months group raising, the group will sell collectively, coordianted by administration working together with Dinari for marketing, so that the group could get best price. With this kind of working together, this group could increase income, and group's living standard increase.

Translated from Bahasa Indonesia by Gwan Liong Ang, Kiva volunteer.

Dalam kehidupan bermasyarakat kita tidaklah bisa hidup hanya tergantung kepada individu kita sendiri tetapi sebagai mahluk sosial kita harus saling tergantung antara satu orang dengan yang lainya. Berdasarkan hal tersebut beberapa anggota masyarakat yang terletak di Desa Pangkung Buluh membentuk suatu kelompok yang diberi Nama Kelompok ” Buluh Sari ”. Kelompok ini diberi nama seperti itu karena berada di desa Pangkung Buluh dan mereka membentuk kepengurusan yang diketuai oleh Ni komang Darmini , Sekertaris Ni Luh Wisadi dan bendhara, NiKomang Nariyati. Kelompok ini dalam kegiatannya melakukan berbagai macam kegiatan yang tujuannya adalah untuk meningkatkan tarap kehidupan kelompok. Adapun kegiatannya itu meliputi kegiatan Simpan Pinjam , Kerja bakti dan kegiatan memelihara ternak babi di rumah masing masing anggota kelompok. Dalam pemeliharaan ternak babinya angota kelompok selama ini melakukannya denga memelihara secara tradisional sehingga dalam hasil yang diperoleh belumlah maksimal. Untuk memaksimalkan hasil usahanya kelompok ini mengajukan permohonan kepada Yayasan Dinari guna nantinya dapat mendampingi kelompok dalam hal pengelolaan kelompok dan juga pelatihan – pelatihan yang diberikan disamping pinjaman dana untuk menambah modal usaha ternak. Melalui pendampingan Dinari kelompok berencana untuk memelihara bibit babi jenis unggul dan membeli pakan yang berkwalitas sehingga akan menghasilkan babi yang sesuai dengan standar pasar Masing –masing anggota kelompok membutuhkan dana sebesar Rp. 1.100.000,- dengan perincian , membeli bibit 4 ekor @ Rp. 250.000,- dan Rp. 100.000.- untuk membeli pakan. Setelah 5 bulan masa pemeliharaan kelompok akan menjual babinya secara bersama sama dengan dikoordinir oleh pengurus bekerja sama dengan Dinari untuk pemasarannya sehingga kelompok akan mendapat harga yang terbaik. Dengan kerjasama seperti ini maka kelompok dapat meningkatkan penghasilannya dan tarap hidup kelompok dapat ditingkatkan. .

loans.use:
To buy pigs of superior type and Quality feed

Membeli bibit babi jenis unggul dan pakan berkwalitas

loans.name: Sokphun

texts.en:
Mrs. Sokphun A. (age 24) married in 2002 and has two children (see photo). She and her family live in a small village across the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers north of Phnom Penh. She is requesting this, her second loan with Maxima, to buy materials for weaving.

Sokphun learned to weave when she was a teenager over the course of a year in which she traveled to a nearby island in the Mekong. It’s not uncommon in this area for young people to apprentice with experienced weavers. Initially they weave the simplest designs and, as their skills improve, their output is exchanged as fees for instruction. Sokphum has since passed along the craft to a younger sister.

In addition to weaving, Sokphun and her husband also farm rice to feed the family. He also does construction work in the area. She explained that the loan will help her by allowing her to buy weaving materials for cash rather than by barter with a middleperson. If she works with a middleperson, she trades two of every three finished pieces just to pay for the weaving thread. She, in turn, gets the sales price from a single piece. If she pays cash for the thread, the cost is cheaper. If she sells for cash, she can increase her profit by as much as 10% or more per piece. Sokphum smilingly expressed confidence that she could easily repay her loan because, with the quality of her weaving, she can sell all she makes.

loans.use: To purchase thread and other weaving materials

loans.name: Mak

texts.en:
Mrs. Mak P. (age 50) and her family live in a small village across the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers north of Phnom Penh. Mak and her husband, married since 1977, have five children, three of whom attend school in their village.

Mak is requesting this, her third loan with Maxima, to buy thread for weaving and pay to set up her loom for weaving. Mak has been working at weaving for three years, a skill she learned, along with one of her daughters, from a fellow villager.

Mak's husband and son also make large (~150 liter) urns for storing rainwater. Her husband has been making these for more than twenty-five years. Mak hopes to continue to grow her business so she can support her children’s studies to the highest possible level.

loans.use: To purchase thread and pay to set up loom for weaving

loans.name: Ni Nyoman Yeni Feray

texts.id:
Yeni Ferayanti at this moment owns 3 mother pig of the Landrace type, and 20 piglets. Her goal is to raise mother pigs so that she does not need to buy piglets. To feed those 3 mother pigs is high cost, especially with feed price soaring lately. The capital help of Dinari would be used to buy feed for 4 months, and also health expenses for her animals. Yeni Ferayanti buys 10 bags of wheat shell clippings, and 10 bags of rice shell clippings for feeding her 3 mother pigs and the piglets. Feeding is twice daily, mornings and evenings. After the piglets reach 3 months old they are sold wholesale 8 piglets at a price of Rp 2,400,000 (Translator's note: 1US$ fluctuates between Rp9000-9500.00), with a nett profit of Rp1,500,000. Within another 3 months the other piglets would be sold for the next month, and she tried to be able monthly to sell piglets. She is in the business, because it helps to support husband's income, who does not have permanent work, to pay for daily living expenses, and children's future.

Translated from Bahasa Indonesia by Gwan Liong Ang, Kiva volunteer.

Yeni Ferayanti saat ini mempunyai 3 ekor induk babi jenis Landrace dan 20 bibit babi . Adapun tujuan memelihara induk agar kedepannya tidak membeli bibit babi. Untuk memenuhi pakan ketiga ekor induknya memerlukan biaya yang tidak sedikit apalagi harga pakan untuk saat ini sedang melonjak tinggi. Dengan bantuan dana dari Dinari dipergunakan untuk mencukupi kebutuhan pakan selama 4 bulan dan biaya kesehatan ternaknya. Yeni Ferayanti membeli 10 sak dedak gandum dan 10 sak dedak padi. Pemberian pakan untuk memenuhi pakan ketiga induk babi dan bibitnya. Pemberian makan dilakukan sebanyak dua kali dalam sehari yaitu waktu pagi dan sore hari. Setelah bibit berumur tiga bulan siap dijual secara borongan sebanyak delapan ekor dengan harga Rp. 2.400.000,- dengan keuntungan bersih sebesar Rp. 1.500.000.- Dalam waktu tiga bulan bibit babi yang lain akan dijual untuk satu bulan berikutnya dan akan diusahakan agar dalam setiap bulan bisa menjual bibit babi begitu seterusnya. Usaha ini ditekuni karena sangat membantu pendapatan suaminya yang tidak mempunyai pekerjaan tetap untuk biaya kebutuhan hidup sehari –hari dan masa depan anak –anak mereka kelak.

loans.use:
To buy pig feed

Membeli pakan ternak

loans.name: Sopheap

texts.en:
Mrs. Sopheap P. (age 45) and her family live in a small village across the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers north of Phnom Penh. Sopheap and her husband (age 50), married for twenty-one years, have three sons. Their youngest attends primary school in the village. The older two dropped out in secondary school because of the cost. (Even though school is ostensibly free in Cambodia, students are asked to pay direct “fees” which can be prohibitive for poor families.)

Sopheap is requesting this, her first loan with Maxima, to buy thread for weaving and to pay to set up her loom (see photo – unprepared loom). Sopheap has been weaving, a skill she learned from an older sister, for six years. Her husband cuts hair in a small wooden hut next to the sole road that passes through their village. He’s been doing this for thirty years. Sopheap hopes to continue to grow her business so she can support her children’s studies. She expressed enthusiasm that they could perhaps get their oldest son to re-enter school because they believe he has much potential.

loans.use: To purchase thread and pay to set up loom for weaving

loans.name: Oeun

texts.en:
Mrs. Oeun C. (age 58) and her family live in a small village across the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers north of Phnom Penh. Oeun and her husband (age 62) have been married since 1971. They have five children, the youngest of whom still studies in high school in the village.

Oeun is requesting this, her first loan with Maxima, to help her son expand his carpentry business in Phnom Penh. He learned his building skills from his father. (See photo for Oeun, husband and one, shy granddaughter.) He has been working at this business for three years.

Oeun's and her husband’s house could be a model of cottage industry. In addition to taking care of the home, Oeun weaves cloth, something she has been doing since she was fifteen years old. Her husband still does construction, repairs, fills motorbike and bicycle tires, and re-charges auto batteries (for electrical use in homes and on farms). Oeun expressed hope that, with this loan, her son will be able to continue to expand his business in the city.

loans.use: To help her son purchase tools and materials to expand his carpentry business

payments.comment:
Dear lender,

Mrs. Oeun Choy has enough money to pay off her loan early. Thank you.

loans.name: Sroeun

texts.en:
Mrs. Sroeun K. (age 28) and her family live in a small village across the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers north of Phnom Penh. Sroeun and her husband (age 31), have been married for eleven years and have two sons, the older of whom studies in primary school in the village.

She is requesting this, her second loan from Maxima, to prepare a second loom and to buy thread for weaving. She has been weaving, a skill she learned by apprenticing on a nearby island, since she was fifteen years old. She has since taught her husband to weave and he will use the second loom. He also works at construction, farms, and raises cows. As is almost universal for Cambodians, Sroeun’s main goal is to maintain or expand her business so she can support the studies of her children.

loans.use: To purchase thread for weaving and to set up a second loom

loans.name: Koin

texts.en:
Mrs. Koin C. (age 47) and her family live in a small village across the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers north of Phnom Penh. Koin and her husband (also age 47), have been married for eighteen years and have four children. The two younger study in secondary school in the village.

Koin is requesting this, her fourth loan from Maxima, to purchase and prepare a second loom and to buy thread for weaving. She has been weaving for six years. Her daughter who will work on the second loom (see photo) learned at the same time as Koin. They said they can each finish about fifteen pieces in a month so they feel they will have no problem paying back the loan.

loans.use: To purchase and set up a second loom and buy thread for weaving

loans.name: Sokheng

texts.en:
Mrs. Sokheng C. (age 49) and her family live in a small village across the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers north of Phnom Penh. Sokheng and her husband (age 53) have been married since 1976 and have six children, four of whom still live at home. The two younger ones study in secondary school in the village and two older ones study in college in Phnom Penh.

Sokheng is requesting this, her first loan from Maxima, to purchase thread for weaving; to buy finished cloth from other weavers for re-sale in Phnom Penh; and to help her son expand his jewelry business. She has been weaving, a skill she learned from her mother, for about thirty years. Five years ago she started buying finished cloth from other villagers for re-sale at the large markets in Phnom Penh.

Sokheng's son (see photo) learned to make jewelry in Phnom Penh. He now produces it at home and sells the finished pieces to middlemen in Phnom Penh. Their main goal is to continue growing their businesses so the remaining kids in school can go on studying. Sokheng also wants to continue saving so they can buy a semi-automatic power loom.

loans.use: To purchase materials for weaving; to buy finished woven cloth for re-sale; and to buy tools and materials to expand her son’s jewelry business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase of more merchandise.

loans.name: Savet

texts.en:
Mrs. Savet Choeung , 46, and her husband, Hol Buntheoun, have been married since 1990 and have four children, ages 10-17. They are both farmers and have been planting and preparing their fields together since marrying. They also raise cows. Savet and Buntheoun both rent and own parts of the land they cultivate (growing potatoes, tomatoes, corn and jicamar).

Savet is requesting a seventh loan from MAXIMA in the amount of $250. She will use this loan to pay for the plowing and preparation of their fields as well as for vegetable seeds. Previous loans were also used for similar purposes. Savet says that it's difficult for them to save profits over the several months of monsoon, when they earn little income, for the larger upfront costs required for the winter planting. As they have been repaying loans successfully for so many years, we feel confident that they will have no difficulty repaying this loan.

loans.use: Buy vegetable seeds and rent additional land for farming

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase of more merchandise.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: For the purchase of merchandise.

loans.name: Houng

texts.en:
Mr. L. Houng , 52, has been married since 1983. He's been a fisherman for over 30 years, a skill he learned as a young man by watching other men in the village. His wife, Phon, has been farming for the same length of time. Almost every day Phon travels to Phnom Penh to sell their vegetables and fresh fish at the markets. They have nine children, ages 3-23, six of whom are attending school. The oldest two are employed.

Houng is requesting a first loan from MAXIMA in the amount of $200. He will use this loan to purchase a new fishing net (US$ 100) and repair his boat engine. Fishing is a profitable business, by Cambodian standards, but the upfront costs are high. This loan will enable Houng to continue his work and earn a good profit without sacrificing the family's standard of living.

loans.use: Buy a new fishing net and repair boat motor

loans.name: Lorn

texts.en:
Mrs.Lorn C., 47, and her husband have been married since 1998. They have seven children, ages 4-30. Two are still in school, but the others are grown and working. Lorn is a farmer and weaver, two skills she utilizes seasonally. She learned to weave from her mother when she was a girl and has now passed on that skill to her own daughter. Her husband also farms.

Lorn is presently requesting her fourth loan through MAXIMA in the amount of $1,000. She will use this loan in part to pay for the plowing and preparation of their fields. Lorn has already sprouted her tomato, watermelon and potatoes, and the transplants are growing quickly in the shaded area she's prepared in front of her home. She will also purchase papaya for planting. Everything is almost ready to plant and she estimates it will take nearly a month to get everything in the ground. It will then be 3 months before she can begin picking the vegetables and a full year for the papaya to produce fruit.

In the meantime, they will support the family with money from the loan, and to provide an added source of income, a portion of this loan will also be used to purchase silk materials and pay for the preparation of the loom for her daughter to weave.

loans.use: Buy raw silk and prepare fields for planting

loans.name: Sat

texts.en:
Mrs. Sat M., 31, has been widowed for 10 years. She lives with her mother and her children in their home near the ferry crossing, across the Mekong outside of Phnom Penh. Her two children, ages 9 and 11, are both attending the local school. Her mother first opened this small, roadside restaurant in front of their home 14 years ago. Sat began working then, helping her mother sells rice porridge and drinks.

Sat is requesting her first loan from MAXIMA in the amount of $200. She will use this loan to expand their business by adding additional items to the menu such as Chinese noodles, coffee, beer, and wine. She will need to purchase kitchen equipment and tableware as well. With these specialty items, they will be able to earn a higher profit for the family. They are expanding the restaurant with more tables and chairs into the front room of their home to seat more customers.

loans.use: Buy food and supplies to expand her little restaurant business

loans.name: Ken

texts.en:
Mrs. Ken M., 28, has been married for 10 years. Her husband is a construction worker and fisherman. They have four children, ages 4-11, three of whom are attending the local school. Ken and her sister learned to weave several years ago from a neighbor. After working for a year, their skill level was good enough to start weaving independently. Now they've been weaving on their own for three years and each has a loom.

Ken is requesting her first loan from MAXIMA in the amount of $200. She will use this loan to purchase silk materials, sewing thread ,and pay for the preparation of her loom. Previously, her mother has borrowed from Maxima to assist her daughters with purchasing materials and buying them looms. Now, Ken M. wants to be more independent and borrow on her own.

loans.use: Buy silk materials and prepare loom

loans.name: Phun

texts.en:
Mr. Phun Y. has been married since 2006. He's been a fisherman for a few years, a skill he learned as a young man by watching other men in the village. Besides fishing, he is a construction worker. He started construction work in 2005. After he finishes construction work, he spends his time fishing in the Mekong River and sells his catch in his village.

Phun's wife, Sreycheat, has been weaving for two years but now she has temporarily stopped weaving as she is preparing to give birth.

Phun is requesting a first loan through MAXIMA in the amount of $100. He will use this loan to purchase a new fishing net (US$ 100). Fishing is a profitable business, by Cambodian standards, but the upfront costs are high. This loan will enable Phun to continue his work and earn a good profit without sacrificing the family's standard of living.

loans.use: Buy fishing nets

loans.name: Norn

texts.en:
Ms. S. Norn is twenty-six years old. She is single and lives with her parent. Norn learned to weave in 1990 from someone in her neighboring village. After working for a year, her skill level was good enough to start weaving independently. She did not finish primary school. Her father is a farmer, and the income of the family not only depends on her weaving but also on her father growing rice and raising animals.

Norn is requesting her second loan from MAXIMA, in the amount of $200. She will use this loan to purchase one buffalo for her father's business of growing rice.

loans.use: To buy one buffalo for growing rice

loans.name: Theam

texts.en:
Mrs. N. Theam, 31, and her husband, Srun Sangva, have been married since 1990 and have five children, one son and four daughters. Theam sells vegetables in her village by bicycle. Her husband is a farmer, and he grows rice and fishes. When he has free time from his farming, he also does construction work.

Theam is requesting a second loan from MAXIMA, in the amount of $100. She will use this loan to purchase rice seed for her husband to grow rice. Both husband and wife hope that this loan will provide them with a better life.

loans.use: Buy rice seed for growing rice

payments.comment:
Dear lender,

Mrs. Theam Nheb has enough money to pay off her loan early before contract.

Thank you.

loans.name: Taing

texts.en:
Mrs. B. Taing, 44, has been married for 22 years. Her husband is a fisherman. He fishes in the river around his village, for their own food and also for sale. They have four sons and one daughter, three of whom are attending the local school. Taing learned to weave in 2004 from a neighbor. After training for a year, her skill level was good enough to start weaving independently. Now she has been weaving on her own for three years.

Taing is requesting her second loan from MAXIMA, in the amount of $300. She will use this loan to purchase silk materials, sewing thread and pay for the preparation of her loom.

loans.use: Buy silk materials and prepare loom

loans.name: Samey's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. U. Samey was selected to be a group leader by members for a loan from Maxima. In the group there are five families, including hers.

1-Mrs. U. Samey (on the left of the photo are Samey and her son) has been a widow for more than 16 years, and she has six sons and three daughters. She is currently in the business of buying and selling many kinds of materials for recycling. She began this business in 2002. Previously, she was in the business of selling fruit at home and being employed to harvest rice for villagers. All of her children are living under her custody. However, some of her children are employed. Two sons work as construction workers and one daughter works at the garment factory. Three are studying and the other children stay at home. She is requesting a loan from MAXIMA for the first time, in the amount of $200. She will use this money to purchase a motorbike.

2- Mrs. SOEURNG Sothea (Sothea and her husband are pictured next to Samey’s son) got married in 1998 and has two sons and one daughter. She has been in the business of planting and selling vegetables since 2005. She is currently planting vegetables in her village and bringing the products to sell at Prek Ho market. Her husband, Mr. Pol Sopheap, has been a construction worker for four years. She is requesting a loan from MAXIMA for the first time, in the amount of $100. She will use this money to expand her business of planting and selling vegetables.

3- Mrs.T. Sokhom (Sokhom and her husband are next to Sothea’s husband) married in 1984 and has three sons and two daughters. She has been in the business of planting, purchasing, and reselling vegetables since 1979. She plants vegetables in her village, and also purchases thE. from villagers. She then resell those products at Ta Khmao market. Her husband, Mr. San Sophal, has been a construction contractor since 1984. Sometimes, he makes a contract for construction work with people in his community and in other villages as well. She is requesting a loan from MAXIMA for the first time, in the amount of $200. She will use this money to expand her business by purchasing more vegetables from villagers to resell at Ta Khmao market.

4- Mr. E. Sophea (Sophea and his wife are pictured next to Sokhom’s husband) married in 2000, and has one son. He has been rU. a motor taxi business in Phnom Penh city since 2004. In the morning, he transports his neighbor, who lives in the same village, to the market. He leaves home early in the morning and returns in the late evening. He is requesting a loan from MAXIMA for the first time, in the amount of $100. He will use this money to repair his motorbike so that he can provide better service for passengers.

5-Mrs. KhU. Sarin (Sarin and her husband are pictured next to Sophea) married in 1957 and has two sons. She has been purchasing and reselling vegetables for the last 12 years. She is currently purchasing vegetables from villagers and taking thE. to resell at Prek Ho market. Her husband, Mr. Prak Thul, is a disabled person and stays at home. Her two sons live under her custody, however, they are employed. One works as a construction worker and another one works at the garment factory. She is requesting a loan from MAXIMA for the first time, in the amount of $100. She will use this money to expand her business by purchasing more vegetables from villagers to resell at Prek Ho market.

loans.use: To repair a motorbike and purchase vegetables for reselling.

loans.name: Muharram

texts.ru:
Muharram M. has been working in the market for the past 11 years. She is a widow and has 5 children. Before, her husband was the sole provider for the family. After his death she was forced to work as a nurse at nights and work in the market during the daytime. In the beginning, she was the only one working on the market. A year after, when she accumulated more capital, her oldest son, Davron, started helping her. After obtaining her first loan from MicroInvest, she started bringing the goods from a different country, which has increased her earnings. Currently, Davron himself is selling goods on the market and Muharram is bringing new inventory. During the past two years, Muharram has been continuously taking out loans from MicroInvest and has become a very good customer. Because of the colder weather, she intends to increase the assortment of her goods by purchasing thicker winter fabrics. Her son, Davron is in the photo. Her own photo was not available.

Translated from Russian by Vasilisa Budnikova. Kiva Volunteer.

Махсумова Мухаррам Екубовна в течение 11 лет торгует на рынке. Не замужем (вдова). Имеет 5 детей. Муж был единственный кормильцем семьи. После его смерти Махсумова Мухаррам была вынуждена, чтобы прокормит семью одновременно работать медсестрой в ЦРБ (ночное время) и торговать на рынке (днем). В первое время она одна работала на рынке. После года деятельности когда она имела не большой собственный капитал ей начал помогать старший сын Даврон. После получения первого кредита от Микроинвест она начала сама привозит, товар тем самим увеличила доход. В данное время Даврон постоянно торгует на рынке, а Мухаррам привозит ему товар. В течение последних 2 лет кредитуется в фонде и является образцовой клиенткой. В связи с наступлением холодов она намерена расширить свой ассортимент посредством приобретения зимних утепленных тканей.

loans.use: Goods' assortment increasing

loans.name: Habibjon

texts.ru:
Habibjon P. has been in the business for more than 15 years. His brother and father are also involved and help him with this production. This is the sole source of income for their whole family. This business was passed from father to children. During the times when Tajikistan was part of the Soviet Union they didn't have any problems with the raw materials. Currently, because the factories that produce metal do not operate, they have to acquire raw materials from neighboring countries where only cash form of payment is accepted. Because they did not have sufficient funds, they were not able to continue their production for some time. Once they found out about the microloan program, MicroInvest, they were able to obtain funding through loans and restart their production. Currently, Habibjon needs financial support to increase his production and acquire more raw materials.

Translated from Russian by Vasilisa Budnikova. Kiva Volunteer.

Пардаев Хабибчон Хасанович занимается производством более 15 лет. Ему в этом деле помогают брат и отец. Это их единственный источник дохода семьи. Это у них идет по наследству от отца к детям. Во времена СССР не было проблем с сырьем. Из-за того, что не работают, заводы по производству метала, они вынуждены закупать сырье в соседних государствах. Они не дают сырье за безналичный расчет. На время они приостановили свое дело из отсутствия средств. После того как они узнали о микрокредитной программе Микроинвест, стали кредитоваться и возобновили производство. На данный момент он нуждается в финансовой поддержке и хочет, увеличит производство.

loans.use: To purchase raw materials

loans.name: Joana Bento

texts.pt:
Joana Bento M. is 44 years old, married, and is the mother of 4 children. She lives in Polana Caniço and has her business in the Chai market in the Maxaquene district in maputo. She sells drinks and sodas. She is new to the program and is looking for a 6.000MT loan to replenish her stocks.

Translated from Portuguese by Jared Wandry, Kiva Volunteer.

Joana Bento M. tem 44 anos de idade, vive maritalmente e é mãe de 4 filhos. Vive no bairo Polana Caniço e tem o seu negócio no mercado Chai no bairro da Maxaquene em Maputo. Vende bebidas e refrigerantes. É nova no programa e pretende tomar um empréstimo de 6.000MT para reforçar o stock do negócio.

loans.use: Increase Inventory

loans.name: Sam Ang

texts.en:
Mrs. S. Sam Ang married in 1990 and has one son and three daughters. She has been in the business of purchasing bananas on contract and reselling them at the market since 2004. She is currently purchasing bananas from villagers who are living nearby, and reselling them at a market in Phnom Penh. Her husband, Mr. Vann Sovin, is a security guard at Kean Svay market.

She is requesting a loan from MAXIMA for the second time, in the amount of $500. She will use this money to purchase bananas on contract from villagers and resell them at the market in Phnom Penh city.

loans.use: Purchasing bananas on contract and reselling at the market

loans.name: Leak

texts.en:
Mr. K. Leak married in 1970 and has three sons and one daughter. He has been in the business of growing rice since 1979, and he also fishes. His spouse, Mrs. Chhum Hean, is currently in the business of making and selling cupcakes at home. She started this business in 2000. All of their sons are married and living in different houses with their families. Only one daughter is living under their custody, but she works at the garment factory.

He is requesting a loan from MAXIMA for the second time, in the amount of $400. He will use this money to purchase a water pumping machine for the farming business.

loans.use: To purchase water pumping machine.

loans.name: Judite Luis

texts.pt:
Judite Luís N. is 46 years old, married, and the mother of 2 children. She lives in the district of Magoanine in Maputo. She entered the program in July of 2005 as a member of the Ahiculene group and started with a loan for 1.800MT. She raises and sells chickens and raises hens for production and sells the eggs in her home. She has had great development in her business having grown the quantity of chicks and hens that she raises. With this loan of $825US she intends to buy food for the chicks and hens, and will build a small house in her yard for her workers.

Translated from Portuguese by Jared Wandry, Kiva Volunteer.

Judite Luís N. tem 46 anos de idade, vive maritalmente e é mãe de dois filhos.Vive no bairro Magoanine em Maputo.Entrou para o programa em Julho de 2005 como membro do grupo Ahiculene e começou com um empréstimo de 1.800MT. Cria e vende frangos e cria galinhas poedeiras para produção e venda de ovos na sua residência.Teve grande desenvolvimento no negócio , tendo aumentado a quantidade de pintos e poedeiras que cria. Vai tomar neste ciclo 20.000MT os quais pretende aplicar na compra de ração para pintos e poedeiras, e ainda costruir uma pequena casa dentro do seu quintal para o empregados.

loans.use: Buy food for chicks and hens, and construct home for workers

loans.name: Borann

texts.en:
Mrs. M. Borann has been widowed since 2005, and has one son. She is now living with her son in Pon-nhea Leu village. She has been in the business of running a grocery store since 1986. She attended only year one at the primary school. Her son, now 22 years old, is assisting her in running the grocery business at home.

She is requesting a loan from MAXIMA for the first time, in the amount of $200. She will use this money to purchase more grocery items for her stock so that she can expand her business.

loans.use: Purchasing more grocery items for her stock

loans.name: Zuhro

texts.ru:
Zuhro has an extensive experience in sewing europian style clothes. It is known that more than a decade ago, after separation from Soviet Union, sewing factories in Tajikistan were not able to provide for their employees because of the outdated equipment. Every factory had to deal with difficulties such as absence of demand and distribution channels, lack of necessary materials and others on its own. The credit provided by MicroInvest will provide substantial help to Zuhro in development of her work in this difficult environment.

Translated from Russian by Vasilisa Budnikova. Kiva Volunteer.

Зухро имеет долгий опыт работы по шитью европейской одежды. Известно, что несколько лет назад швейные цеха не смогли обеспечить своих работников, доставшихся в наследство от Советского Союза, технически морально устаревшие цеха. Каждое из этих цехов самостоятельно преодолевало трудности проблемы переходного периода, такие как, отсутствие рынка сбыта, трудности с сырьем и материалами и др. Кредит, получивший с Микроинвест, оказал значительную помощь в продвижении ее работы.

loans.use: Additional fabrics

loans.name: Savriniso

texts.ru:
Savriniso D. has three children. She works as a seamstress in the local sewing factory. She was not able to make modern, trendy clothing with her old sewing machine, so she started seasonal work like dying of leather goods. Then she got an advice to turn for help to MicroInvest. She took out a loan and purchased a new sewing machine and was also continuing to repair leather goods.

Translated from Russian by Elena Fedorchuk, Kiva Volunteer.

Джураева имеет троих детей, она работает портнихой в городском швейном цеху. Раньше ее старая швейная машинка не позволяла шить современную одежду, тогда она занялась сезонной работой, т. е. Покраска кожаных изделий. Ей посоветовали обратиться в Микроинвест. Получив кредит, она обновила свою швейную машинку и параллельно занималась реставрировать кожаные изделия.

loans.use: Clothes making

loans.name: Aventina Amélia

texts.pt:
Aventina Amélia B. is 36 years old, married, and the mother of 2 children. She lives in Polana Caniço and has a stand in the Ferroviário district where she sells drinks and sodas, cigarettes, and has a pool table. She entered the program in June of 2006 with a loan of 6.000MT. Now she is going on her 4th loan cycle and is looking for $350US to replenish stock.

Translated from Portuguese by Jared Wandry, Kiva Volunteer.

Aventina Amélia B. tem 36 anos de idade, vive maritalmente e é mãe de dois filhos. Vive no bairro Polana Caniço e tem uma barraca no bairro Ferroviário onde vende bebidas e refrigerantes, cigarros e tem uma mesa de bilhares.Entrou para o programa em Junho de 2006 com um empréstimo de 6.000MT. Vai agora para o 4º ciclo de empréstimo e vai tomar 8.000MT com visrta e reforçar o stock .

loans.use: Increase inventory

loans.name: Ann

texts.en:
Mrs. L. Ann married in 1986 and has one daughter, three years old. She learned to weave Kroma (Cambodian scarves) from her neighbor and started her own Kroma production in 2000. Her husband, Suon Soeurn, makes looms for villagers. He is currently also serving in the military in the province of Kandal. In the future, they hope that borrowing money from MAXIMA will help them to send their daughter to school to pursue a higher education.

She is requesting a loan from MAXIMA for the first time, in the amount of $500. She will use this money to expand her Kroma production by purchasing extra cotton fiber.

loans.use: Purchasing cotton fiber for producing Kroma (scarves)

loans.name: Askar

texts.ru:
Askar, as many others, was making scanty earnings at his former job which were not even enough to support his family. He took out a loan started a business selling stationary. His income was now enough to support his elderly parents who were no longer able to support themselves. During the past five years his partnership with MicroInvest has been a success.

Translated from Russian by Elena Fedorchuk, Kiva Volunteer.

Атаев как и многие другие получал на прежней работе мизерную заработанную плату, на которую невозможно было содержать семью. Получил кредит , занялся бизнесом, продажа канцелярскими товарами. Стал обеспечивать свою семью, где уже родители были пенсионерами , которые не в состоянии были обеспечивать их. В течении пяти лет он с успехом сотрудничает с Микроинвест.

loans.use: Sale of stationary

loans.name: Phoeun

texts.en:
Mrs. T. Phoeun married in 1968 and has three sons and one daughter. Two of her children are married and living in different houses with their families. Her daughter is also married. Currently, the youngest son, her daughter and son-in law are living under her custody. Her daughter and son-in-law are helping her to make and sell Chinese cake. Currently, her youngest son is working as a construction worker.

She has borrowed money from MAXIMA three times already. Now she is requesting another loan in the amount of $1,000. She will use this money to purchase a motorbike for her son-in-law to run a motor taxi so that he can support the family.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike for her son-in law to run a motor taxi

loans.name: Lurdes

texts.pt:
Lurdes Luis is 43 years old and a single mother of 3 children. She lives in the Magoanine district in Maputo. She entered the program in June of 2005 as a member of the Ahiculene group. She sells various food products such as cooking oil, sugar, cornmeal, rice, potatoes, onions, vegetables, etc. She has grown substantially in her business and in her social economic situation. When she entered the program she lived with her parents, and with the loans she was able to build her own home. She is taking a $625US loan and intends to restock her business and invest in some home improvements.

Translated from Portuguese by Jared Wandry, Kiva Volunteer.

Lurdes L. tem 43 anos de idade e mãe solteira de 3 filhos. Vive no bairro Magoanine em Maputo.Entrou para o programa em Junho de 2005 como membro do grupo Ahiculene. Vende diversos produtos alimentares como óleo alimentar, açúcar, farinha de milho, arroz, batata, cebola, legumes, etc.Tem estado a avoluir bastante tanto no negócio , como na situação sócio económica. Quando entrou para o programa, vivia na residência dos seus pais e com os empréstimos conseguiu construir residência própria.Vai tomar 15.000MT e pretende,para além de reforçar o stock, investir também no melhoramento da sua residência em construção.

loans.use: Increase inventory and construction

loans.name: Yakubu

texts.en:
Yakubu A. is a trader at Moree Junction near Cape Coast. He sells provisions such as milk, milo, frytol cooking oil, oats, Pepsodent, tape batteries, bulbs, Dettol, and cheese. He is married with two children ages 9 and 5 years. His wife is also a trader who manages another store owned by her husband.

Yakubu is a hardworking man. He also sells groundnut, maize, beans, and yams. He brings them from the northern part of the country and supplies them to some junior and senior high schools within and outside Cape Coast. He is a well-known trader. He also sells cosmetics, mineral water, and minerals such as Coca Cola, Malta, and Fanta.

One major challenge that Yakubu faces is the high cost of transportation from the northern part of the country to supply his customers. He is therefore asking for a loan of US $1,200 to enable him to pay for the high cost of transportation and bring in more food such as maize, yam, groundnut, and sweet potatoes to supply to the junior and senior high schools. He also wants to buy more creams and body lotions to fill his cosmetics store.

loans.use: To bring in more food such as maize, yam, groundnut, sweet potatoes to supply to the junior and senior high schools.

loans.name: Phun

texts.en:
Miss T. Phun is single and lives with her retired parent, together with her younger sister. She is currently in the business of buying and reselling silk products and weaving silk as well. She learned to weave silk from her neighbor and started her silk production in 2002. Her younger sister, who learned to weave from her neighbor, also weaves silk at home.

She has borrowed money from MAXIMA three times already. Now she is requesting another loan in the amount of $500. She will use this money to purchase silk materials, sewing thread, and pay fees for selecting and preparing silk on her sister's and her looms so that they can expand their silk production businesses.

loans.use: To purchase silk materials, sewing thread, and pay fees for selecting and preparing silk on the looms

loans.name: Pov

texts.en:
Mrs. H. Pov married in 1998 and has two sons and one daughter. She has been in the business of raising pigs since 2000. In addition, she produces rice alcohol. She does not only sell alcohol, but also has the waste from the production of rice alcohol as food for her pigs. Her husband, Mr. Sok Phoeun, before commencing his business of providing a transportation service, raised pigs at home with his wife, Mrs. Pov.

She has borrowed money from MAXIMA four times already. She is now requesting a loan in the amount of $500. She will use this money to expand the pig raising business.

loans.use: To expand pig raising business

loans.name: Alice Adu

texts.en:
Alice Adu – G. is a trader at Moree Junction. She sells fante kenkey, a popular Ghanaian food, sweet potatoes, and body creams. She has seven children. She is a hardworking woman. In order to take very good care of her family, she also travels to the northern part of the country to buy maize, groundnuts, and yams to supply them to her customers in and around Cape Coast. She is well-known as a supplier of maize and groundnuts. Occasionally, she also sells body creams and lotions.

One major challenge Alice faces is that she has received lots of orders from her customers for the supply of maize, yams and groundnuts, but the prices of these foodstuffs are relatively lower in the northern part of Ghana than the south. Alice is therefore asking for a loan of US $800 to enable her to travel to the north to buy the foodstuffs (maize, yam, groundnuts, and sweet potatoes) to supply to her customers.

loans.use: To travel to the north to buy the foodstuffs (maize, yam, groundnuts, and sweet potatoes) to supply to her customers.

loans.name: Neema

texts.en:
“What kind of business does Mrs. K. run?” I asked. “Kuku, kuku!” replied my colleague emphatically. Who or what is ‘Kuka’ you may ask, as I did while client and colleague alike enjoyed my confusion! Kuka means chickens in Swahili. I hope simple chickens aren’t an anti-climax after such intrigue, but simple chickens are what support Neema K., her husband Moses and their ten year-old daughter Rachel.

Neema accessed a loan from SELFINA early in 2007 to establish a business raising and selling chickens, which she has repaid in full. She is now requesting a loan of $700 to expand this business. She wants to buy more kuka!

About the microloan partner:

SELFINA is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through leasing and leaseback facility as a practical way to achieve economic and social emancipation of women.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro Leasing. Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus termed not-creditworthy by financial institutions as they lack tangible collateral assets. This leads to poor financial support hence poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes.

SELFINA buys and leases equipment to women. Where a client needs working capital SELFINA buys equipments from the said client extending a loan to her and then leases back the same equipment – a process called sale and leaseback arrangement.

loans.use: Neema would like to purchase additional chickens to raise and sell.

loans.name: Shokir

texts.ru:
Shokir is a father of three children and a husband of a happy wife, a good family man. For two years in a row he has been receiving loans from MicroInvest which helped him develop the manufacturing and sales of wool and knitted fabrics. Shokir is planning to open another store which he will rent for expansion of his business. Previously he only had one employee, and now he hires four. Shokir wants to continue to take out loans with great pleasure.

Translated from Russian by Elena Fedorchuk, Kiva Volunteer.

Шокир отец троих детей и муж счастливой жены, хороший семьянин. Кредитуется уже два года в Микроинвесте ,с помощью чего у него хорошо развились производство и торговля шерстянными и трекотажными изделиями.В дальнейшем хочет открыть еще один магазин или взять в аренду для расширения бизнеса.Раньше у него было всекго один сотрудник, а сейчас уже четверо.Он с радостью,хочет продолжить свое кредитование.

loans.use: Expanding the manufacturing of knitted fabrics.

loans.name: Bola

texts.en: Bola A. is 53 years old, divorced with 3 children, and hails from Lagos, Nigeria. She sells beans and peppers and grinds tomatoes. She has been in this business since 2000 and requests a loan to buy a grinding machine.  She believes this will help her serve her customers better.

loans.use: To buy more grinding machine

loans.name: Hannah Amissah

texts.en:
Hannah Amissah B. sells provisions such as milk, milo, Pepsodent, sugar, rice, and biscuits. She is married with one daughter aged 14 years. Her husband is a photographer, and his income is low. To help with the family finances, Hannah works very hard. She also buys eggs and distributes them to her customers. Her shop is also located at a busy market here in Cape Coast.

One major challenge that Hannah faces is that she has to make an advance payment before she receives her supply of eggs. At the moment, she has lots of orders from her customers for the supply of eggs. Hannah is asking for a loan of US $1,100 to enable her to buy more eggs and supply them to her customers.

loans.use: To buy more eggs

loans.name: San

texts.en:
Mrs. M. San married in 2004 and has one son. For the last three years, she has learned to weave silk from her friend in Koh Dach Island. Her husband is in the business of providing a transportation service. He drives a truck to carry goods and fruits for a private company, which he started almost six years ago. In addition, the family also farms, including growing rice and raising animals. Mrs. M. San borrowed money from Kiva through MAXIMA in the amount of US$500, and she has paid off this loan and is now requesting a second loan from Kiva.

This time, she is requesting a loan in the amount of $400. She will use this money to purchase silk materials, sewing thread, and pay fees for selecting and preparing silk on the loom.

loans.use: To purchase silk materials, sewing thread, and pay fees for selecting and preparing silk on the looms

loans.name: Zebi

texts.ru:
R. Zebi Amonovna is selling children's clothing for the past 16 years. She is married and has five children. After the collapse of the Soviet Union (USSR) she and her husband lost their jobs. Her husband is currently unemployed. Zebi had to start selling on the market to feed her family. Her older son was also helping her. As her children grew older her income was not enough. Her older son had to go to Russia to find work. He was sending home US$100 a month, but it was still not enough. In the early 2006 Zebi obtained a loan to expand her business. She started buying merchandise in large quantities (wholesale) for a lower price and selling it retail or semi-wholesale. Her younger son, Zubaidullo is helping her with the business. Zebi wants to be more competitive and intends to travel to Bishkek, the Republic of Kyrgyztan, herself to purchase merchandise which will allow her to start selling wholesale.

Translated from Russian by Elena Fedorchuk, Kiva Volunteer.

Расулова Зеби Амоновна в течение 16 лет торгует детской одеждой. Замужем. Имеет 5 детей. После распада СССР они остались без работы. Муж в данное время без работы. Чтобы прокормить семью она была вынуждена выйти на базар торговать. Старший сын помогал ей. По ходу взросления детей ее доход не был достаточен. Её старший сын вынужден был поехать на заработки в Россию. Он присылал по 100$ в месяц. Но и этого было, не достаточна и в начале 2006 года она для расширения своего бизнеса получила кредит. Она закупает большими партиями товар (оптом) по низкой цене и продает в розницу и мелким оптом. Ему сейчас помогает ее младший сын Зубайдулло. Чтобы быть более конкурентоспособным она намеревается ездить сама за товаром в Бишкек (Республика Кыргызстан), что позволит ей перейти в оптовую торговлю товарами.

loans.use: Increase the assortment of goods and purchase new products for winter

loans.name: Stella

texts.en: Stella S. is 29 years old, married with 2 children, and hails from Lagos, Nigeria.  She is a stylist and also sells weavers and attachments and has been in business for 9 years. She is requesting a loan of $400 to  buy more weavons and attachments.

loans.use: To buy more weavons and attachments

loans.name: Gafur

texts.ru:
A. Gafur is 34 years old, married and has a daughter. Since he was young, his hobby was making jewelry, and when he was older he became an apprentice of a professional jeweler. After achieving good results Gafur moved to Russia where he worked for five years. Now he has come back to Tajikistan and wants to open a small shop where he will manufacture and repair rings and other jewelry. Gafur needs sufficient funds to purchase the necessary equipment and decided to turn to MicroInvest for a loan.

Translated from Russian by Elena Fedorchuk, Kiva Volunteer.

Алиев Гафур,возраст 34 года женат имеет дочь.С малых лет увлакался производством ювелирных зделий и был в юнности учеником у умелого ювелира.После достяжения хороших результатов он уехал в Россию и проработал там 5 лет,и теперь вернувшись на Родину хочет открыть свой ларек по ремонту и изглтовлению колец и различных изделий.Для этого у него нехватает финансов для приобретения необходимого оборудования.И гафур решил кредитоваться в Микроинвесте.

loans.use: Purchase equipment for jewelry manufacturing.

loans.name: Change Group

texts.en: Bdilika ("Change" in English) is a group of entrepreneurs featured in the photograph. It is is composed of Mamka A., Pili Nasoro, Kasanda M. and Rehema Shaban, who are all residents of the Buguruni area of Dar Es Salaam. S. and Manka run restaurants, while the other two own groceries. All four of them are recipients of the business and entrepreneurship skills training organized by YOSEFO, and have long ago realized the importance of doing business together. They are each in need of US$300 to help them boost their respective businesses.

loans.use: Business expansion

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Youth Self Employment Foundation (YOSEFO) - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Hagah

texts.en:
Hagah B. sells yams. She is married and has four children. Her husband is also a trader. Hagah is a hardworking woman. She travels to the northern part of Ghana to bring yams to sell. She also supplies schools with large quantities of yams. She is well known at Tantri, where she sells her yams.

One major challenge that Hagah faces is that she is not able to bring the yams in large quantities because of lack of capital. She always receives orders from her customers for the supply of yams. She is therefore asking for a loan of US $1,000 so that she can bring the yams in large quantities from the northern region to supply to her customers.

loans.use: To bring the yams in large quantities from the northern region and supply to her customers.

loans.name: Toyin

texts.en: Toyin W. is 47 years old, married with 5 children, and hails from Lagos, Nigeria. She sells cooked food and drinks in her community. She has been in  business since 1997. She requests a loan of $625 to buy refrigerator to cool her drinks.

loans.use: To buy a refridgerator for cooling drinks

loans.name: Eng Heang

texts.en:
Mrs. R. Eng Heang married in 2001 and has two daughters. She is currently in the business of weaving silk. She learned to weave silk from her aunt in 2000 and started her silk production in the same year. She trained her husband, Mr. Muth Socheat, to weave in 2002. Both of them are currently weaving silk at home. Moreover, Mr. Socheat is also growing rice and raising animals.

She is requesting a loan from MAXIMA for the first time in the amount of US$500. She will use this money to purchase silk materials, sewing thread, and pay fees for selecting and preparing silk on their looms.

loans.use: To purchase silk materials, sewing thread, and pay fees for selecting and preparing silk on the looms

loans.name: Subgroup C Of Group Tujikwamue Ukonga

texts.en:
Mohamed, age 37, is married and has 2 children (14 and 7 years old). His brother-in-law’s children (16 and 17) also live with them. In 1991, Mohamed started two different businesses - used clothing and tomato sales. As a part of his tomato business, Mohamed buys a box of tomatoes at US$9-14, depending on the market price, and sells it with a daily profit of US$6-7. In his other business, Mohamed buys each piece of used clothing at about US$2-3 and manages to earn a daily profit of about US$9. He uses his combined profits to increase the stock of both businesses and to pay school fees for his children. In addition, he employs an assistant to help with both businesses.

Mohamed is the leader of Subgroup C of group Tujikwamue Ukonga (Tujikwamue meaning “progressing from one stage to another” in Swahili, and Ukonga being the location), which totals 55 members. He will be sharing this loan with his subgroup members: Mariamu S. (fish sales), Rabia A. (fish and market sales), Joyce D. (market sales), Khadija A. (clothing and charcoal sales), Mery M. (clothing sales), and Jane V. (market sales). Mohamed knows his subgroup well, as they are all neighbors and have shared 2 previous loans from Tujijenge Tanzania, which they paid back successfully.

Mohamed used the previous loans to buy more stock of used clothing and tomatoes. With this new loan, he plans to once again purchase more used clothing.

loans.use: Business expansion

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en:
Agnes J. runs Faith Electronics, a busy shop in the busy town of Kibaha Kwa Matias on the outskirts of Dar es Salaam, Tanzania. Here she sells various electrical items, from cables, sockets and plugs to radios, phones and televisions. Her business supplements her husband’s business and helps to support their three children, Muldina, 20, Yuhana, 18 and Daniel, 16, as well as her 15 year-old ‘aunty’, Thabitha (her mother’s youngest sister). Agnes requires a loan of $700 to buy more electrical gadgets to sell to Tanzania’s new high-tech generation!

About the microloan partner:

SELFINA is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through leasing and leaseback facility as a practical way to achieve economic and social emancipation of women.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro Leasing. Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus termed not-creditworthy by financial institutions as they lack tangible collateral assets. This leads to poor financial support hence poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes.

SELFINA buys and leases equipment to women. Where a client needs working capital SELFINA buys equipments from the said client extending a loan to her and then leases back the same equipment – a process called sale and leaseback arrangement.

loans.use: Agnes would like to purchase additional stock to expand her electronics business.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: L. Mary is 35, married, has 2 children and hails from Afromedia in Lagos, Nigeria. She sells provisions, drugs and drinks, and has been in business since 1999 and.  She requests a loan of $625 to buy more provisions, drugs and drinks for sale.

loans.use: To buy more Drugs, Provisions and Drinks

loans.name: Gulbahor

texts.ru:
Gulbahor is 44 years old. She is married and is raising 4 children. Her husband works, and Gulbahor also has a business at the local market. Her range consists of small goods. She has been working with MicroInvest-Tajikistan for more than a year. She is hoping to receive a loan in order to expand her business.

Translated from Russian by Susie Armitage, Kiva Volunteer.

Гулбахор 44 года, она замужем и воспитывает 4 детей. Ее муж тоже работает, а сама Гулбахор занимается бизнесом на местном рынке. Ее ассортимент составляют мелкие товары. С Микроинвест сотрудничает более 1 года. она собирается получить новый займ для расширения своего бизнеса.

loans.use: to expand her business

loans.name: Adam

texts.en: Adam M. is 34 years old and lives in the Buguruni are of Dar Es Salaam. He runs a Video hall showing the latest movies, both local and international. His hall accommodates fifty people and charges US$0.5-1.5 per movie, depending on the demand. Adam would like to borrow US$525 to help him buy new facilities for the hall.

loans.use: Business expansion

loans.name: Seki

texts.en: Seki T. is 25 years old, married and has 2 children and hails from Lagos, Nigeria. She sells clothes and tailors clothes for people living in her community. She requests a loan of $400 to buy more clothes and tailoring material. This will help her serve her customers better.

loans.use: To buy more clothes & tailoring material

loans.name: Sophoeun

texts.en:
Mrs. N. Sophoeun married in 1997 and has three children - one son and two daughters. She began weaving silk at home in 1993 after she learned to weave silk from her mother. Her husband, Mr. Kroeun Sophy, plants tomatoes, which he started in 1990. In addition, he also raises cows for reselling. They both did not receive very much education. Therefore, all of their children are being sent to primary school in the village nearby. They expect that with the existing business and receiving a loan from MAXIMA, their living conditions will be better in the future, so that they can afford to support all of their children's higher education.

She has borrowed money from MAXIMA five times already. Now she is requesting a loan in the amount of $200. She will use this money to purchase silk materials, sewing thread, and pay fees for selecting and preparing silk on the new loom she has recently set up. She will also hire her neighbor to weave.

loans.use: To purchase silk materials, sewing thread, and pay fees for selecting and preparing silk on the new loom

loans.name: Bose

texts.en: A. Bose is 35 years old, married, and hails from Afromedia in Lagos, Nigeria. She sells books to students in  school.  She requests a loan to buy more textbooks for sale.

loans.use: To buy more textbooks

loans.name: Firuza

texts.ru:
Firuza is married and has one child. Her husband is working in Russia, and Firuza trades at the market. She rents a small store where she sells warm blankets and household goods. She is hoping to receive a loan from MicroInvest-Tajikistan in order to expand her business.

Translated from Russian by Susie Armitage, Kiva Volunteer.

Firuza замужем, имеет 1 ребенка. Ее муж на заработках в России, а Фируза выходит на рынок торговать. Она арендует маленький магазинчик где продает теплые одеяла и различные товары для дома. Она собирается получить займ в Микроинвест для расширения своего бизнеса.

loans.use: to expand her business

loans.name: Abigirl

texts.en: Abigirl B. is 45 years old, married and has 6 children.  She hails from Afromedia in Lagos, Nigeria. She grinds pepper, tomatoes and beans. She has been in this business since 1984 and requests a loan of $625 to buy another grinding machine.

loans.use: To buy another grinding engine

loans.name: Khusrav

texts.ru:
Khusrav Gadoyboyevich R. has been trading at the market for 7 years and has a lot of business experience. He purchases goods wholesale and sells them at retail prices. Right now, he is the only person in his family who is earning money. His brother could not find a job in Tajikistan and left to work in Russia. Currently, Khusrav's mother and father help him in his business. He set up his trading stall at the central market. This business is the only source of income for the family. In order to increase his working capital, Khusrav needs financial support.

Translated from Russian by Susie Armitage, Kiva Volunteer.

Рачабов Хусрав Гадойбоевич торгует на рынке уже 7 лет и имеет в этом деле большой опыт. Он, закупает товар оптом и продает розницей. На данный момент он единственный в семе кто зарабатывает. Его брат не находя работу уехал на заработки в Россию. Ему в данное время ему в торговле на рынке помогают отец и мать. На данный момент он обустроила свою торговую точку в центральном вещевом рынке. Данный бизнес является основным источником дохода семье. Чтобы увеличит оборотный капитал, он нуждается в финансовой поддержке.

loans.use: to increase the assortment of goods sold and purchase winter products

loans.name: Aun

texts.en:
Mrs. M. Aun is a widow with 3 children - two sons and one daughter. She began her business of selling household tools in 2003. All of her children are working; one daughter works in a garment factory, and two sons are construction workers.
