She expects that with the existing business and receiving a loan from MAXIMA, their living conditions will be better in the future.

She is borrowing money from MAXIMA for the second time in the amount of US$1,000. She will use this loan to purchase household tools for expanding her business.

loans.use: To purchase household tools for reselling in her village

loans.name: Jamila Mohamed And Mariam Rajab Chande Group

texts.en: Jamila M. and Mariam R. C. are two entrepreneurs who do their business jointly. Jamila runs a restaurant and, at the same time, makes Kanga (a type of local attire made by tie and die). Mariam runs both a restaurant and a ladies' beauty salon in the Buguruni area. They have been involved in their respective businesses for the past six years, and are now asking for a loan of US$400 each to expand their business.

loans.use: Business expansion

loans.name: Jitaidi Group

texts.en: The photograph, from left to right, features Eva P., Sophia M. and Juma K., who call themselves JITAIDI, meaning "strive high". They each own a different business, but, nevertheless, work in a partnership. Their businesses are located in the Buguruni area of Dar Es Salaam. Juma runs a shop selling used clothing and shoes, while Sophia runs a restaurant, and Eva sells charcoal. Each of them is in need of US$350 to help them boost their business in expectation of the approaching Christmas, since business earnings typically rise around this season.

loans.use: Business expansion

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Youth Self Employment Foundation (YOSEFO) - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Rachel

texts.en: Rachel F. is a 45 year old mother of 5 and hails from Afromedia in Lagos, Nigeria. She sells provisions, foodstuffs and drinks. She is requesting a loan to buy more provisions, foodstuffs and drinks.  She has been a LAPO member for 2 years.

loans.use: To buy more provisions, foodstuffs and drinks

loans.name: Madex

texts.en: Ayola Madex is 33 years old, married and has 2 children.  She comes from Afromedia, a semi-urban area in Lagos, Nigeria. She sells drinks, bread and eggs. She requests a loan to buy a refrigerator and 10 crates of eggs.

loans.use: To buy more eggs and a refrigerator

loans.name: Subgroup G In Group Tujikwamue Ukonga

texts.en:
Tatu, age 30, runs a food sales business at a local slaughter house, which she started in 1989. She sells different types of food from 4pm until 8am the next day. Each night, she serves around 80 customers, earning a profit of about US$9. With this profit, she pays for additional food stock and for general household expenses. She also employs two women to help her cook and serve the food, and pays about US$27 a month in rent for the stall. Tatu is a single mother of 4 children (15, 13, 10, and 8 years old) and is also looking after her mother.

Tatu is the leader of Subgroup G in group Tujikwamue Ukonga (Tujikwamue meaning “progressing from one stage to another” in Swahili, and Ukonga being the location), which totals 55 members. Tatu will be sharing this loan with her subgroup members: Fidea M. (food sales), Palina W. (chicken sales), Zainabu A. (food sales), Flora R. (food sales), Rehema S. (food sales) and Emanuel M. (used clothing sales). She knows her subgroup well, as they are neighbors and have shared 2 previous loans together, which they paid back successfully.

Tatu used the previous loans to increase the quantity of different food items in her stall. The new loan, too, will be used for the same purpose. In particular, Tatu plans to buy big sacks of baking flour, cooking oil, and charcoal. She also wishes to open a day business for food sales.

loans.use: Business expansion

loans.name: Halimakhon

texts.ru:
Halimakhon J. has been trading at the market for ten years. She is married. Her husband earns money, but it isn't enough to support their family. Her son left to work in Russia, and Halimakhon has to work at the market in order to feed her family. Her children are grown and Halimakhon dreams of helping them out, but the income from her business is not enough. She learned about the micro-credit program at MicroInvest Tajikistan and would like to increase the assortment of goods she sells, in hope of increasing her income. Due to the coming cold weather, she plans to widen the range of goods offered.

Translated from Russian by Susie Armitage, Kiva Volunteer.

Жураева Халимахон в течение 10 лет торгует на рынке. Замужем. Муж зарабатывает, немного для того чтоб прокормит семью. Сын клиентки уехал на заработки в Россию. Клиентка вынуждена зарабатывать на рынке, чтобы прокормит семью. Дети взрослые, мечтает, их обустроит. Доход, получаемый от бизнеса не достаточен. Она узнала о программе микрокредитования Микроинвест и хочет увеличить товар посредством чего хочет увеличить свой доход. В связи с наступлением холодов она намерена расширить свой ассортимент.

loans.use: to increase the assortment of goods sold

loans.name: Khanoglan

texts.en:
Khanoglan is a married man with two children. He was born in 1961. He lives in Salyan region, in the Yenikand village.

He has his own farming business. Because Khanoglan wants to improve his business, he is applying for a loan of $1,200 to buy a plot of land.

loans.use: To buy a plot of land

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Komak Credit Union - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Tajueleen

texts.en: Tajueleen S. is 30 years old, married with 4 children and comes from Afromedia in Lagos, Nigeria. She sells kpomon (cow skin) at the neighborhood market. She has been a LAPO member for 2 years. She is requesting for a loan to buy more kpomon (cow skin) to sell.

loans.use: To buy more cow skin to sell

loans.name: Asha

texts.en: Asha S. is a 55 year-old mother of five, resident of the Buguruni area of Dar Es Salaam. S. keeps poultry, a business she has been running for the past five years. She keeps both broiler and layer hens. Asha's business customers are mainly owners of restaurants in the Buguruni area. She is asking for a loan of US$475 to buy more chicken, in order to scale up her business for the Christmas season.

loans.use: Business expansion

loans.name: Amudat

texts.en: Amudat O. is a 40 years old mother of 4 and hails from Okoko in Lagos, Nigeria. She sells cosmetics and jewelery. She has been in this business since 1998 and is requesting for the loan buy more cosmetics and jewelery.

loans.use: to sell more cosmetics and jewelry.

loans.name: Zubeda

texts.en:
Red and yellow and pink and green… Mama H. makes and sells a rainbow of batik cloths. She established her business in 2004 and has received one loan from SELFINA which has been repaid in full. She now requires a loan of $525 to expand her business by buying new dyes and cloth. Her business, along with her husband Kayumba’s salary, supports their two children as well as five other dependents. With your assistance Mama H. will continue making rainbows-- purple and orange and blue…

About the microloan partner:

SELFINA is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through leasing and leaseback facility as a practical way to achieve economic and social emancipation of women.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro Leasing. Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus termed not-creditworthy by financial institutions as they lack tangible collateral assets. This leads to poor financial support hence poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes.

SELFINA buys and leases equipment to women. Where a client needs working capital SELFINA buys equipments from the said client extending a loan to her and then leases back the same equipment – a process called sale and leaseback arrangement.

loans.use: Zubeda would like to purchase additional cloth and dyes for her batik business.

loans.name: Oluchi

texts.en: Oluchi E. is a 30 year old mother of one.  She sells drugs, provisions and drinks. She is a LAPO member. She has being in her business for the past 7 years and requests the loan to buy more provisions, drinks and drugs to serve her customers better.

loans.use: To buy more drugs, provisions and drinks

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mambo from Dar!* In a busy corner of the city, Mama Lunyunga runs a dawa (shop), where she sells food and soft drinks. She is a 33 year-old mother of three and the profits from her business supplement her husband Aron’s salary from his job at the head office of Tanzanian prisons to support their children, as well as Mary’s niece and nephew. Mama Lunyunga has already successfully repaid two loans from SELFINA and now requires another to expand her business further by increasing her stock. She thanks you very much for your support – ashante sana! *Hello from Dar es Salaam, Tanzania

About the microloan partner:

SELFINA is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through leasing and leaseback facility as a practical way to achieve economic and social emancipation of women.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro Leasing. Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus termed not-creditworthy by financial institutions as they lack tangible collateral assets. This leads to poor financial support hence poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes.

SELFINA buys and leases equipment to women. Where a client needs working capital SELFINA buys equipments from the said client extending a loan to her and then leases back the same equipment – a process called sale and leaseback arrangement.

loans.use: Mary would like to purchase additional stock for her food and soft drink store.

loans.name: Emin

texts.en:
Emin (his father is pictured) is a single man who lives in Salyan region, in the Yenikand village.

The 26-year-old has been in the farming business for three years. Now, he needs a loan of $475 to buy fertilizer.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Komak Credit Union - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Titilayo

texts.en: Titilayo L. is a stylist, who expanded her business greatly in her business since she became a member of LAPO 2 years ago. She is a 35 year old mother of 3 and hails from Okoko, a semi-urban sector in Lagos, Nigeria. She requests the above loan to buy weavons and attachments and a dryer. This will help her serve her customers better.

loans.use: To buy more weavons and attachments and a dryer

loans.name: Mayasa

texts.en:
Mayasa is a 28 year-old mother of three, a resident of Buguruni area. She has been selling newspapers for the past four years. She buys them in large quantities and supplies them to the street vendors and the city's office employees.
Mayasa is in need of US$425 to help her expand her newspaper sales business.

loans.use: Business expansion

loans.name: Identity

texts.en:
The entrepreneur is 27 years old. He has 2 children, and his mother and father live with him. They are all living in a rented house. He has a carpentry shop in Kirkuk. He applied to borrow $1200 for the following: purchase new wood and some raw materials for the shop, hire two jobless to help him in the shop, paint the shop, and make some advertising. He wants to increase his income and develop himself.

Disclaimer: This entrepreneur is from a volatile region where the security situation remains unsettled. Lenders to this business should be aware that this loan may represent a higher risk and accept this additional risk in making their loan.

Note: Personally identifiable attributes of this entrepreneur have been altered to protect him or her (i.e. blacking out portions of the entrepreneur in his/her picture, altering his/her first or last name, etc.).

loans.use: Purchase new wood and some raw material

loans.name: Tawa

texts.en: Tawa S. is a 40-year-old mother of 4 and hails from Ajamgbadi in Lagos, Nigeria.   She sells frozen food, drinks and pure water. She has being in this business since 1997. She requests a loan to buy more frozen food and drinks to improve her business.

loans.use: To buy more frozen food, drinks and pure water

loans.name: Mahija

texts.en:
Welcome to Mwashee Milk & Soft Drinks, run by 32 year-old Mahija N.. At her colourful and well-organised shop you can sample the tasty treats in the front display case; fresh and delicious cakes (top) and ‘egg chops’ (bottom), literally ‘snacks made from eggs’ (and flour), which are a little like mini doughnuts.

Mahija established the business in 2005 and requires a loan of $850 to expand it by purchasing additional stock (and hopefully adding some new scrumptious snacks). The business, in addition to her husband Ally’s salary, helps to support Mahija’s two young children, Jafari, 11 and Mashehe,8.

About the microloan partner:

SELFINA is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through leasing and leaseback facility as a practical way to achieve economic and social emancipation of women.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro Leasing. Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus termed not-creditworthy by financial institutions as they lack tangible collateral assets. This leads to poor financial support hence poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes.

SELFINA buys and leases equipment to women. Where a client needs working capital SELFINA buys equipments from the said client extending a loan to her and then leases back the same equipment – a process called sale and leaseback arrangement.

loans.use: Mahija would like to purchase additional stock for her drink and snack store.

loans.name: Murayo

texts.en: Moriyo T. is a 37 year old married woman with 2 children from Okoko, Lagos, Nigeria. She sells garri in the market. She has been a LAPO member and requests a loan to enable her buy more garri for sale.

loans.use: To buy more garri

loans.name: Gladys

texts.en: Gladys A. is a 40 year old single parent, has 4 children, and hails from Okoko in Lagos, Nigeria. She sells drinks and local gin (Ogogoro). She has been with LAPO as a leader of a union for the past 2 years and has also being in business since 1997.  She is requesting for a loan of $800 to buy more drinks for sale.

loans.use: To buy more drinks and local gin (Ogogoro)

loans.name: Parvin

texts.en:
Parvin (his sister is pictured) was born in 1985 and lives in Yenikand village, in the Salyan region.

Parvin, who is single, has four years of experience in this business. Now, he needs a loan of $1,200 to buy baling presses for improving his business.

loans.use: To buy baling presses

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Komak Credit Union - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Sevnaz

texts.en:
Sevnaz is a widow with two children. The 45-year-old lives with her two children in Yenikand village, in the Salyan region.

Ten years ago, Sevnaz started a farming business to support her family. To improve her farming business, she requests a loan of $1,200. Sevnaz wants to buy fertilizer and pesticides so she can get a higher yield.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and pesticides

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Komak Credit Union - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Neema

texts.en:
This is Mrs. Neema D., proudly displaying a new delivery to add to her collection of intricately patterned batik cloths and stylish local dresses. However beautiful her cloths may be though, there are many other shops in Dar es Salaam selling similar stock, so competition is stiff. Neema therefore wants to strengthen her business by diversifying. She requires a loan of $275 so that she can also begin selling tailoring supplies such as buttons, pins, zips, needles, lining…small things, yes, but things that are in high demand in Tanzania, where most people have their clothes custom-made (this is actually cheaper and obviously much more interesting!) and then mended when they tear or fray. Neema hopes that this new venture will generate a constant turnover that will enable her to continue assisting her husband to support their family of three children.

About the microloan partner:

SELFINA is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through leasing and leaseback facility as a practical way to achieve economic and social emancipation of women.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro Leasing. This leads to poor financial support hence poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes.

SELFINA buys and leases equipment to women. Where a client needs working capital SELFINA buys equipments from the said client extending a loan to her and then leases back the same equipment – a process called sale and leaseback arrangement.

loans.use: Neema would like to diversify her business by purchasing and selling tailoring supplies.

loans.name: Adventina

texts.en:
At 41, Mrs. M. has raised six children and successfully managed her own seamstress business for almost ten years. And she is still looking ahead, planning to purchase new equipment and materials to expand her business. For this she requires a loan of $850 and trusts she will find a Kiva lender as energetic and committed as herself!

About the microloan partner:

SELFINA is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through leasing and leaseback facility as a practical way to achieve economic and social emancipation of women.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro Leasing. Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus termed not-creditworthy by financial institutions as they lack tangible collateral assets. This leads to poor financial support hence poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes.

SELFINA buys and leases equipment to women. Where a client needs working capital SELFINA buys equipments from the said client extending a loan to her and then leases back the same equipment – a process called sale and leaseback arrangement.

loans.use: Adventina would like to purchase new equipment and material to expand her sewing business.

loans.name: Abigirl

texts.en: Abigirl I. is 42 years old, married with 4 children, and hails from the town of Ubanmu in Lagos, Nigeria. She sells all kinds of fruit. She has been in business since 2003 and a LAPO member since 2004. She is requesting a loan to enable her buy more fruit to sell.

loans.use: To buy more fruit

loans.name: Nkechi

texts.en: Nkechi M. is 44 years old, married and has 7 children.  She hails from Okoko in Lagos, Nigeria. She sells foodstuffs.  She learned this from her mother and has been in the business since 2002. She requests a loan of $275 to buy more foodstuffs to sell.

loans.use: To buy more Foodstuffs

loans.name: Gunay

texts.en:
Gunay (her mother is pictured) was born in 1982 and lives in Khaladj village, in the Salyan region. She is single and has her own farming business.

Four years ago, she started her farming business. Now, she needs a loan of $1,200 to buy a plot of land to expand her farming.

loans.use: To buy a plot of land

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Komak Credit Union - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en: Victoria J. is 60 years old, married and has 2 children, and hails from Ishasi town in Lagos, Nigeria. She is a farmer and produces corn, okra and other vegetables. She has been in this business since 2001 and requests the loan to buy more seedling and to maintain the farm.

loans.use: For seedling & farm maintenance

loans.name: Amina

texts.en:
Sit back and relax! 27 year-old Amina sells a range of mattresses, sofa seats and comfy cushions. She established the business in 2002, which she has guided from strength to strength and now generates a profit of about $360 per month. She has generously shared the fruits of her labour not only with her own children, Iddy and Fakhi but with two of her sister’s children, Warda and Amina, whom she now cares for. Never one to rest on her laurels (or her cushions!) she is now requesting a loan of $1,125 to expand her business by purchasing additional stock.

About the microloan partner:

SELFINA is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through leasing and leaseback facility as a practical way to achieve economic and social emancipation of women.

loans.use: Amina would like to purchase additional mattresses and cushions to sell.

loans.name: Roswita

texts.en:
This is Mama Happy, somehow managing to suppress her usually big smile, which I can only assume inspired her nickname. She is married to her husband Didas, with whom she has two children, Edentruda, 5 and Edson, 18 months. Mama Happy established a business selling women’s and children’s clothing in 2002 and has since repaid two loans from SELFINA. She now requires another loan to purchase additional stock. She sends her thanks and a smile!

About the microloan partner:

SELFINA is engaged in economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through leasing and leaseback facility as a practical way to achieve economic and social emancipation of women.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro Leasing. Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus termed not-creditworthy by financial institutions as they lack tangible collateral assets. This leads to poor financial support hence poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes.

SELFINA buys and leases equipment to women. Where a client needs working capital SELFINA buys equipments from the said client extending a loan to her and then leases back the same equipment – a process called sale and leaseback arrangement.

loans.use: Roswita would like to purchase women's and children's clothing to sell.

loans.name: Mashhura

texts.ru:
Mashhura sells children's clothing in Isfara's central market. She is married and has two children. She has been in business for a long time and her income goes to support her family. She has been working with MicroInvest-Tajikistan for more than a year. She is planning to get a loan in order to buy warm children's jackets

Translated from Russian by Susie Armitage, Kiva Volunteer.

Машхура занимается продажей детской одежды на центральном рынке г. Исфары. Она замужем и имеет 2 детей. Бизнесом занимается давно и доход от него расходуется на семью. С Микроинвест сотрудничает больше года. Она собирается получить новый займ для закупа теплых детских курток.

loans.use: to buy children's jackets

loans.name: Veronica

texts.en:
Affectionately nick-named Mama Bright, which literally means ‘the mother of Bright’, in reference to her 1 year-old son Bright, Veronika P. is certainly bright and creative. She established a business making and selling African batik cloth earlier this year and now generates a profit of approximately $100 per month. She requires a loan of $300 to expand her business by purchasing additional cloth and dye.

About the microloan partner:

SELFINA is engaged in economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through leasing and leaseback facility as a practical way to achieve economic and social emancipation of women.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro Leasing. Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus termed not-creditworthy by financial institutions as they lack tangible collateral assets. This leads to poor financial support hence poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes.

SELFINA buys and leases equipment to women. Where a client needs working capital SELFINA buys equipment from the said client extending a loan to her and then leases back the same equipment – a process called sale and leaseback arrangement.

loans.use: Veronica would like to purchase additional cloth and dye for her batik business.

loans.name: Rafiga

texts.en:
Rafiga is a 25-year-old with three years of experience in the farming business. She is single and lives in Khaladj village, in the Salyan region.

Rafiga requests a loan of $1,200 to buy fertilizer and pesticides for improving her business.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and pesticides

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Komak Credit Union - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Gulnafisa

texts.en: Gulnafisa, 21, is not married. Her assortment of goods includes foodstuffs. Sales profits contribute to her family’s budget, as Gulnafisa lives with her parents. Gulnafisa joined MicroInvest in September and has already earned a reputation as an exemplary borrower. Gulnafisa plans to use her new loan for further expansion of her business.

loans.use: For further expansion of her business.

loans.name: Kamil

texts.en:
Kamil is a father of two children. He lives with his family in Yenikand village, in the Salyan region.

He has seven years of experience in the farming business. Now, he needs a loan of $1,200 to buy fertilizer.

loans.use: He would like to buy fertilizer

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Komak Credit Union - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Hadjaga

texts.en:
Hadjaga is a young man who has his own business. He has sold clothes for three years. He is 25 years old, single and lives in Khaladj village, in the Salyan region.

Hadjaga plans to expand his shop and buy a lot of clothes to attract more clients. He requests a loan of $1,200 to realize his plans.

loans.use: To expand his shop

loans.name: Arzu

texts.en:
Arzu (her brother is pictured) was born in 1979 and lives in Khaladj village, in the Salyan region.

She is single and has run this business for five years. She requests a loan of $1,200 to buy foodstuffs for increasing the number of her clients.

loans.use: To purchase foodstuffs

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Komak Credit Union - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Rose

texts.en: Rose O. is 45 years old, a widow with 5 children. She hails from Okoko town in Lagos State, Nigeria. She sells bread to most of the shops in her community. She has been in this business since 1999.  She needs the loan to enable her to buy more bread for sale.

loans.use: To buy more bread

loans.name: Muazzamhon

texts.ru:
Muazzamhon, 41, widowed mother of 3 children. She sells clothing for children on the central market. Recently, Muazzamhon was struck by the tragic loss of her husband. Now, Muazzamhon is solely responsible for the welfare of her family. She has been a MicroInvest client for half a year. Muazzamhon wants to use this loan to expand assortment of winter clothing.

Translated from Russian by Aleksandr Zhuk, Kiva Volunteer.

Muazzamhon 41 год, замужем имеет 3 детей. Занимается продажей детской одежды на центральном рынке. Недавно у нее случилось несчастье в семье – умер муж. Теперь вся ответственность по содержанию семьи лежит на ней. С Микроинвест сотрудничает полгода. Хочет получить новый займ для расширения зимних видов детской одежды

loans.use: To expand assortment of winter clothing

loans.name: Subgroup H Of Tujikwamue Ukonga

texts.en:
Dominic L., age 40, is married and has 4 children (12, 8, 6 and 4 years old). He owns a beef butchery which he opened in 1993. He pays around US$55 for rent per month and hires 2 men to help him sell the meat. Dominic buys the meat at around US$2 per kilo and sells it for US$3. He serves about 40 customers per day during the week and 50 customers over the weekend, making a profit of about US$14 a day. He has been using the profit to cover family expenses and to increase the stock of meat in his store.

Dominic is the leader of Subgroup H of group Tujikwamue Ukonga (Tujikwamue meaning “progressing from one stage to another” in Swahili, and Ukonga being the location), which totals 55 members. He will be sharing this loan with his subgroup members: Amani M. (tailoring), Aminatha T. (chicken & clothing sales), Maria D. (clothing sales), Sara M. (clothing sales), Patricia P. (medicine and other sales), and Stephano M. (butchery). He knows his subgroup members well, as they are all neighbors and, as a group, have already successfully paid back their first loan from Tujijenge Tanzania.

With the previous loan, Dominic purchased a larger stock of meat for his butchery. He is planning to use the new loan to buy more stock and to also renovate his butchery.

loans.use: Business expansion

loans.name: Gullu

texts.en:
Gullu lives in Kirkhchirak village, in the Salyan region. She is 39 years old and single.

Gullu has been in the farming business for 15 years. She needs a loan of $1,200 to buy fertilizer and pesticides to improve her farming.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and pesticides

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Komak Credit Union - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Alaba

texts.en: Alaba F. is 35 years old and a mother of 2. She hails from Mushin in Lagos State, Nigeria. She is into the production and supply of sugar and salt. She is a LAPO member. Alaba needs the loan to buy materials for production of salt and sugar for sale.

loans.use: To buy more material for production of salt and sugar

loans.name: Adadun

texts.en: Adadun O. is 38 years of age, happily married with 2 children. She hails from Mushin in Lagos State, Nigeria. She is a stylist and also sells shoes, bags and clothes in her store. Adadun has been in LAPO for three years. She needs the loan to buy more shoes, bags and clothes for sale.

loans.use: To buy shoes, bags and clothes for her store

loans.name: Mujuba

texts.ru:
Mujuba, 50, is married and has 5 children. She is selling chicken eggs on the central market. Because stable jobs are lacking, Mujuba’s business provides an important stream of income for her family. Mujuba earned a reputation of responsible MicroInvest client. She plans to use the new loan to expand her business.

Translated from Russian by Aleksandr Zhuk, Kiva Volunteer.

Мучубе 50 лет, замужем имеет 5 детей. она занимается куплей продажей куриных яиц на центральном продуктовом рынке. Так как постоянной работы нет доход от бизнеса является одной из статей ее семейного бюджета. В Микроинвест она показала себя как ответственная и пунктуальная клиентка. Новый займ собирается потратить на расширение своего бизнеса.

loans.use: Business expansion

loans.name: Idayatu

texts.en: Idayatu A. is 50 years of age and a mother of 2. She hails from  Mushin in Lagos State,Nigeria.  She sells plastics and has been a LAPO member for three years. Idayatu has been in this business since 1998 and needs  the loan to buy more plastic products for sale.

loans.use: To buy more plastics for sale

loans.name: Bose

texts.en: Bose O. is 36 years old, a mother of 4,  and comes from Mushin in Lagos State, Nigeria. She produces body cream, powder and detergent. She has been  with LAPO as a secretary for 3 years. Bose has been in her business since the year 2002 and needs the loan to buy materials for her products.

loans.use: To buy materials for her products

loans.name: Djeyhun

texts.en: Djeyhun has sold spare parts for 3 years. He is 22 years old and lives in Khaladj village in the Salyan region. This single man needs a loan of $1200 to expand the area of his shop and purchase spare parts.

loans.use: to expand the area of his shop

loans.name: Aminat

texts.en: Aminat Y. is  43 years old, a mother of 5, and comes from Mushin in Lagos State, Nigeria. She is a caterer. Aminat has been in this business since 2001 and needs the loan to buy catering materials

loans.name: Latifat

texts.en: Latifat A. is 35 years old and married with 2 children. She hails from Mushin in Lagos State, Nigeria. She sells books. She has been in this business since the year 2000 and needs a loan of $450 to buy more books for sale.

loans.name: Gulmira

texts.ru:
Gulmira sells tableware sets on the market in Spitamen. Her husband works, while Gulmira’s mother-in-law takes care of Gulmira’s child. Gulmira’s uncle delivers the goods from a wholesaler. Gulmira plans to use this loan to expand her business.

Translated from Russian by Aleksandr Zhuk, Kiva Volunteer.

Гулмира занимается продажей наборов посуды на рынке Спитамена. Ее муж работает, а за ее ребенком ухаживает свекровь дома. Поставками посуды занимается дядя Гульмиры, который привозит их с оптового рынка на собственной машине. Гулмира собирается расширить ассортимент посуды и для этого хочет получить займ.

loans.use: Business expansion

loans.name: Omolara A

texts.en: Omolara M. is 35 years old, married and has 3 children. She  lives in Mushin, Lagos State, Nigeria. She sells rice, beans and garri, a food made from cassava tubers. She has been in her business since 2002. Omolara is requesting a loan to buy more rice, beans and garri for sale.

loans.use: To buy more foodstuffs for sale

loans.name: Mumikatu

texts.en: Munikatu I. is 35 years, married with 4 children. She lives in Mushin, Lagos State, Nigeria. She sells ice fish. Mumikatu has been in this business since 1999. She needs the loan to buy more fish for sale.

loans.use: To buy more fish for sale

loans.name: Nuraddin

texts.en: Nuraddin is a father of three children. He and his family live in Yenikand village in the Salyan region. He has a farming business, where he grows vines. 8 years ago he started this business to meet the demands of his family. Nuraddin needs a loan of $1200 to buy  vine props for getting a rich yield.

loans.use: to buy vine props

loans.name: Bakare

texts.en: Bakare G. is 38 years old, married and has 2 children. She hails form Mushin in Lagos State, Nigeria. She sells drinks and provisions. Bakare has been in business since the 1997 and needs the loan to buy more provisions and drinks for sale.

loans.use: To buy more drinks and provisions for sale

loans.name: Muhimahon

texts.ru:
Muhimahon is a very energetic woman. She is 42 and has 3 children. Muhimahon is engaged in numerous businesses including sales of dried fruits, cattle farming and taxi services. Her MicroInvest loans Muhimahon uses to purchase food for cattle and expand her small cattle farm business.

Translated from Russian by Aleksandr Zhuk, Kiva Volunteer.

Muhimahon очень энергичная жизнь. Хотя ей 42 года и у нее трое детей, она успевает заняться многими видами бизнеса. Это включает в себя и торговлю сухофруктами, и откорм скота и даже она успевает таксовать на своей старенькой машине. В Микроинвест она получает займы для развития бизнеса – откорм скота. Новый займ она планирует потратить на закупку корма для своей мини–фермы.

loans.use: To purchase food for cattle

loans.name: Ushindi Group

texts.en: Sada A., 53, Hidaya M., 33, and Rehema A., 32, featured in the photograph, together form a group called USHINDI (SUCCESS, in English). They have been engaged in business for the past five years and, in the process, have realized the importance of doing business as a group. They each have succeeded in expanding a small business of one dollar profit a day to a relatively bigger business that now earns each one of them a daily profit of US$8. Sada sells ladies clothing, both new and used; Hidaya sells wood, mainly for carpentry and construction purposes, and Rehema runs a grocery. All three of them live and work in the Buguruni area of Dar Es Salaam. Together, they are asking for a loan of US$1,200 - each of them is in need of US$400 to help them expand their business.

loans.use: Business expansion

loans.name: Latifat

loans.name: Florence

texts.en: Florence A. is married with 5 children. She is 62 years of age and comes from Mushin in Lagos State, Nigeria. She sells fried meat,cooked egg and engages in the typing of documents. Florence has been in her business since 2002 and needs the loan to buy a photocopying machine.

loans.use: To buy weavon and attachment

loans.name: Caminando Hacia El Futuro (Walking Towards The Future) Group #1

texts.en:
Nery is 38 years old and raises her two daughters (ages 14 and 17) by herself. Her business is gasoline sales. She buys gallons from the nearby town of Samana and sells it in small quantities to her community. Most of her customers are motorcycle drivers who are passing by, or her neighbors.

Other businesses in this group include: small convenience stores and clothing sales. They meet in one of the associate’s backyard. Their community is about 20 minutes from the nearby town of Samana.

Nery found out about Esperanza through her cousin, who is a loan associate in a different Bank of Hope. She decided to start her own group so she and her neighbors could take out a group loan. Right now, this is the only group in the larger Bank of Hope, but as they start their second loan cycle more neighbors are becoming interested and are starting to form additional groups.

With her first loan, Nery was able to buy more gasoline upfront which she was able to sell to her community and increase her profit. She is going to use this second loan to gradually increase the amount of gasoline she can buy and sell.

Andres O. not present when this photo was taken

NOTE: This is a group loan. Nery is one of five microentrepreneurs in her Bank of Hope solidarity group, all of whom have gone through Esperanza's business training courses. Each of the five members will receive a share of this $750 loan for their respective businesses and will be accountable to each other for repaying their share of the loan together. This group-lending methodology ensures that members cooperate to help one another repay their loans and invest wisely in their businesses and families.

loans.use: She is going to use this second loan to gradually increase the amount of gasoline she can buy and sell

loans.name: Kehinde

texts.en: "If not for LAPO what would I have done’’ says Mrs. Kehinde A. who is very proud of her financial backing from LAPO. She lives in Mushin in Lagos state, Nigeria. She sells provisions, foodstuffs and clothes.  She has been in business since 2002. She needs the loan to buy more provision, foodstuffs and clothes to sell.

loans.use: To buy more provisions, foodstuffs and clothes to sell

loans.name: Tope

texts.en: Tope Baloggun is a 44 year old single parent of 3 children. She comes from Mushin in Lagos State, Nigeria. She buys drugs and sells to neighboring villages where there are no chemist drugs. This has been her business since 1998 and requests the loan to buy more drugs to sell.

loans.use: To buy more drugs for sale

loans.name: Ida

texts.en: Ida is 21 years old, and a mother of a child aged 7. Together with her husband, A., they run a small farm, a business they started after becoming an MBK member. They plant rice, vegetables, and other plants. She usually sells her plants and earns $16.50 per week. Ida requests a loan to expand her business by buying some fertillizers and seeds etc. Then, they will be able to plant more and increase profits. She is willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers, etc.

loans.name: Mshikamano Group

texts.en:
(Left to Right) Sulemani C., Hassani B. Issa, Athumani M., 
Zuberi M., are four had working Men forming the Mshikamano group. They jointly own a carpentry workshop at Buguruni in Dar Es Salaam City. They have been running this workshop for the past 4 years and ever since they joined resources, their workshop is expanding.  Each is in need of USD 312.5 which will jointly  help them buy more wood cutting and screwing machines  for the workshop.

loans.use: BUY EQUIPMENTS FOR THE WORKSHOP

loans.name: Iyabo

texts.en: Iyabo B. is a 41 year old widow with four children and hails from Mushin in Lagos State, Nigeria. She sells cooked food. She has been in business for the past three years and needs the loan to buy more foodstuffs.

loans.use: To buy more foodstuffs for cooking

loans.name: Maisha Group

texts.en: The photograph features Tatu M., Halima M., Husna O. and Noefita B. , who are all hard-working women forming the MAISHA group. They have been doing business for the past ten years, and are beneficiaries of the business and entrepreneurship skills training programmes organized by the Youth Self Employment Foundation. Sulemani and Hassani run their own restaurants in Vingunguti, while the other two women each own a grocery. Each one of the group's members needs US$300 to help them boost their business.

loans.use: Business expansion

loans.name: Arike

texts.en: Arike A. is a 47 year old mother of 5 and hails from Mushin in Lagos State. She sells foodstuffs and she has been in her business since 1992 and need the to buy more foodstuffs for sale.

loans.use: To buy more foodstuffs for sale

loans.name: Tarsih

texts.en: Tarsih is 38 years old, and a mother of a child aged 15. She has a small shop that sells snacks, and some household goods. She usually earns US $5.50 per day with a small profit. Her husband, M., works at a repair shop but does not have a regular income. Tarsih requests a loan to buy more goods to fill her shop. She is a member of MBK and is willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: To buy more goods to fill her shop

loans.name: Kubirat

texts.en: Kubirat I. is happily married with four children. She is 38 years old and comes from Oshodin in Lagos State, Nigeria. She sells plywood. She has been in her business since 1993. She is the leader of her Union and needs the loan to buy more plywood for sale

loans.use: To buy more plywood for sale

loans.name: Cristo Viene (Christ Is Coming) – Group #3

texts.en:
Maria, pictured second from right, is 65 years old and only has an elementary school education. She has two children and 11 grandchildren. Maria’s husband, Ramon, used to work as a butcher, but had to undergo several operations in the hospital and now is no longer able to work. Because of this, Maria is the sole supporter of her family.

Maria runs a small business selling clothing from her house. Because there are no big clothing stores in Sanchez, Maria goes to the nearby larger cities, such as Santiago and San Francisco, to buy her wares. Most of her clients are her friends and neighbors. She is able to make enough of a profit to support herself and her husband.

Maria’s group meets in her house to repay their loans. Other businesses in her loan group include fishing supplies sales and a seamstress. Also pictured: Ana Garcia, their loan officer, who makes the 40 minute trip out to Sanchez to be at their biweekly repayment meetings.

NOTE: This is a group loan. Maria is one of five microentrepreneurs in her Bank of Hope solidarity group, all of whom have gone through Esperanza's business training courses. Each of the five members will receive a share of this $750 loan for their respective businesses and will be accountable to each other for repaying their share of the loan together. This group-lending methodology ensures that members cooperate to help one another repay their loans and invest wisely in their businesses and families.

loans.use: To invest in their businesses

loans.name: Basirat

texts.en: O. Basirat is a 35 year old mother of 4 and comes from Mushin in Lagos state, Nigeria. She sells plywood. She has been in her business since 1996 and needs the loan to buy more plywood for sale.

loans.use: To buy more plywood for sale

loans.name: Ida

texts.en: Ida is 29 years old, married with one child, aged 6. She started farming after becoming a member of MBK. She needs a loan to buy fertilizer and seeds for her farm. Her husband, Agus, does not have regular income. Ida usually earns US $10 per week and she hopes that the loan will help her increase her income for her family. She is willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: To buy more fertilizer and seeds

loans.name: Rafatu

texts.en: Rafatu A. is a 40 year old mother of 5 and comes from Apapa, in Lagos state, Nigeria. She sells plywood. She has been in this business for the past 14 years and needs the loan amount to buy more plywood to sell.

loans.use: To buy more wood

loans.name: Kemi

texts.en: Kemi O. is a 45 year old mother of 4. She comes from Mushin in Lagos state, Nigeria. She sells cement. She has been a LAPO member for the past 3 years and needs a loan to enable her buy more cement for sale.

loans.use: To buy more cement

loans.name: Jihudi Group

texts.en: Featured in the photograph, from left to right, are Salome K., Heleni K., Juliana R. and Sultan Dibibi S.. Together, they make up the JIHUDI group, and all have been involved in the food sales business for the past five years, running groceries in Buguruni. Together, they are asking for a loan of $1,000: each of them will use $250 to boost their business.

loans.use: Business expansion

loans.name: Paz Y Progreso (Peace And Progress)– Group #2

texts.en:
Oferlina, pictured first from left, is 29 years old and has a middle school education. She is not married and raises her three children by herself - two girls (ages 8 and 6) and a one-year old boy (pictured with her).

Her business is selling fishing supplies to fishermen at the nearby beach, El Valle. She sells nets, lines and bait, which she buys at the nearby city of Samana. Oferlina speaks of wanting to provide a better life for her children. She uses the profits from her small business to buy food for her family, and to keep reinvesting in her business. She will use the next loan from Esperanza to invest in more fishing supplies.

The other businesses in her group include gasoline sales and a small convenience store. Oferlina lives in a very rural community, and her group meets in an open area next to her house (where they are pictured). Their loan officer’s name is Yacueline Jones, a kindhearted young woman who has been working with Esperanza ever since the Samana branch opened five years ago. Members of his group have been Esperanza loan associates for 2 years, and they have collectively paid back 3 previous group loans.

NOTE: This is a group loan. Oferlina is one of five microentrepreneurs in her Bank of Hope solidarity group, all of whom have gone through Esperanza's business training courses. Each of the five members will receive a share of this loan for their respective businesses and will be accountable to each other for repaying their share of the loan together. This group-lending methodology ensures that members cooperate to help one another repay their loans and invest wisely in their businesses and families.

loans.use: She will use the next loan from Esperanza to invest in more fishing supplies

loans.name: Seni

texts.en: Seni is 42 years old and a mother of a child aged 12. Together with her husband, Z., she sells  vegetables at their house. They usually earn US $25 per week. Previously, she sold food, but the income in that business was decreasing, so now she would like to concentrate on vegetable sales. She requests a loan to expand her business by planting and selling various vegetables. She is willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: To plant and sell more and varied vegetables

loans.name: Janeth

texts.en:
Janeth is a single woman, age 28, who cares for two of her sister’s children, Gladness, 13, and Goodluck, 9. In 2005 she established a business raising and selling chickens. She would like to expand her business and increase her profit in order to support her family. She requires a loan of US $275 to purchase more chicks to add to her growing brood!

SELFINA is engaged in economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through leasing and leaseback facility as a practical way to achieve economic and social emancipation of women.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro Leasing. Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus termed not creditworthy by financial institutions, as they lack tangible collateral assets. This leads to poor financial support, hence poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes.

SELFINA buys and leases equipment to women. Where a client needs working capital SELFINA buys equipments from the said client, extending a loan to her and then leases beck the same equipment – a process called sale and leaseback arrangement.

loans.use: To purchase additional chicks to raise for sale.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase and restocking of grocery store goods

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Diversify and increase her merchandise selection

Rodiah would like a loan to expand her business and is willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: To add capital

This is Sifa M. who runs a shop, selling a variety of clothing in downtown Dar. She is 42 years old and married to Samuel with whom she has three children, Minaeli, 23, Angela, 20, and Yonaza, 15. She has operated her shop since 2006 and requires a loan of $275 to purchase new stock, which she will sell at a profit. She thanks you for your support.

SELFINA is engaged in economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through leasing and leaseback facility as a practical way to achieve economic and social emancipation of women.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro Leasing. Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus termed not creditworthy by financial institutions as they lack tangible collateral assets. This leads to poor financial support hence poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes.

SELFINA buys and leases equipment to women. Where a client needs working capital SELFINA buys equipments from the said client extending a loan to her and then leases beck the same equipment – a process called sale and leaseback arrangement.

loans.use: To purchase additional stock.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Improve the corral where she raises her animals.

loans.name: Funke

texts.en: Funke A. is a 39 year old mother of 3 that hails from Mushin, urban sector in Lagos state, Nigeria. She sells fabrics, shoes and bags. She began her business in 1995 and needs a loan to buy more clothes, shoes and bags to increase her sales.

loans.use: To buy more clothes, shoes and bags

loans.name: Glory

texts.en:
Glory is a young entrepreneur of 29 who opened her first business just this year. She runs a Duka la Dawa (pharmacy, in Swahili) and requires a loan of $275 in order to increase both the quantity and range of her stock. She is determined to expand her business amidst the hustle and bustle of Kibaha Kwa Matias, a busy town on the outskirts of Dar es Salaam, Tanzania.

SELFINA is engaged in economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through leasing and leaseback facility as a practical way to achieve economic and social emancipation of women.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro Leasing. Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus termed not creditworthy by financial institutions as they lack tangible collateral assets. This leads to poor financial support, hence poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes.

SELFINA buys and leases equipment to women. Where a client needs working capital, SELFINA buys equipments from the said client extending a loan to her, and then leases back the same equipment – a process called sale and leaseback.

loans.use: To increase the quantity and range of products at her pharmacy.

loans.name: Las Amazonas (The Amazons) - Group #1

texts.en:
Blasina, pictured 3rd from left, is 38 years old and has one daughter who is 16 years old. She is married, and her husband, whose name is Amado, is the chief police sergeant in town.

There are no large clothing or shoe stores in Sanchez, so Blasina has several catalogues from larger stores from the nearby big city of San Francisco. Her neighbors, as well as some of her friends who attend the university, place orders from her catalogues. She then picks up these orders and is able to charge a small commission fee. With her subsequent loan from Esperanza, Blasina wants to expand her client base and buy more of her popular items up front.

This will be the group's second loan. They have been Esperanza loan associates for 7 months, and they collectively paid back their first group loan. The group meets in Blasina’s house in the small fishing town of Sanchez. Other examples of businesses in Blasina's group include seamstress and gasoline sales. Also pictured: Ana G., their loan officer, who makes the 45 minute trip out to Sanchez every two weeks to collect their payments.

Angela P. P. and Martha L. C. not present when this photo was taken

NOTE: This is a group loan. Blasina is one of five microentrepreneurs in her Bank of Hope solidarity group, all of whom have gone through Esperanza's business training courses. Each of the five members will receive a share of this loan for their respective businesses and will be accountable to each other for repaying their share of the loan together. This group-lending methodology ensures that members cooperate to help one another repay their loans and invest wisely in their businesses and families.

loans.use: To expand her client base and buy more of her popular items up front

loans.name: Lawrencia

texts.en: Lawrencia E. is a 51 year old widow with 9 children. She comes from Igbenerin in Lagos state, Nigeria. She sells provisions and drinks. She began her business in 2005 and requests a loan to buy more provisions and drinks for sale. She thanks you.

loans.use: To buy more provisions and drinks

loans.name: Vivian

texts.en:
In 2000 Vivian Y. opened a shop selling men’s and women’s clothing. She now requires a loan of $275 to expand her line of clothing (ball gowns, clown costumes?). She hopes to increase her profits so that with her husband, Sijao, and she can continue to support her son Kelvin, 12 and her younger sister Maria, 18.

SELFINA is engaged in economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through leasing and leaseback facility as a practical way to achieve economic and social emancipation of women.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro Leasing. Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus termed not creditworthy by financial institutions as they lack tangible collateral assets. This leads to poor financial support hence poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes.

SELFINA buys and leases equipment to women. Where a client needs working capital, SELFINA buys equipments from the said client, extending a loan to her and then leases back the same equipment – a process called sale and leaseback.

loans.use: To purchase new stock to expand the line of clothing.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Sero Lease and Finance Ltd. (SELFINA) - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Masrika

texts.en: Masrika is 24-years old and a mother of a child, aged 5. Fish livestock has been her business since before being a member of MBK. She can earn US $3 per day. Her husband, S., is an employee who earns US $40 per month. She is requesting a loan to buy some fish, and fish food, etc. She hopes that she can earn more income to support her family needs, and is willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: To buy fish, fish food, etc.

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en:
Victoria K. is a multi-talented multi-tasker! She is married to John Shumari and has two children, Yoeli, 7, and Wingrac, 3. In 2002 she established a business selling Christian literature and books. She now wants to expand this business by purchasing additional goods, as well as open a new business raising guinea fowl for sale. Christ and guineas? Books and fowl? It may not make sense, but I’m sure it will make money! For these business ventures, Victoria requires a loan of $525 and trusts she will find some Kiva lenders who appreciate her eclectic range of enterprises! 

SELFINA is engaged in economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through leasing and leaseback facilities as a practical way to achieve economic and social emancipation of women.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro Leasing. Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus termed not creditworthy by financial institutions, as they lack tangible collateral assets. This leads to poor financial support, hence poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes.

SELFINA buys and leases equipment to women. Where a client needs working capital, SELFINA buys equipments from the said client extending a loan to her and then leases beck the same equipment – a process called sale and leaseback.

loans.use: To purchase Christian books and guinea fowl!

loans.name: Helen

texts.en: Helen E. is married with 4 children, is 38 years of age and hails from Lagos state, Nigeria. She sells provisions and Drinks. She has been in business since 2002 and needs the loan to enable herself to buy more provisions and drinks for sale.

loans.use: To buy more provisions and drinks

loans.name: Ebere

texts.en: Ebere I. is 28 years old, married and has a child. She comes from Afromedia, in Lagos state, Nigeria. She sells drugs and provisions. She has been in business since 2002 and needs the loan to buy more drugs and provisions for sale.

loans.use: To buy more drugs and provisions

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase additional pipes

loans.name: Arnasih

texts.en: Arnasih is 41 years old and a mother of a 14-year-old daughter. She and her husband, H., run a small farm--a business they started after becoming members of MBK. They plant rice, vegetables, and many other plants. They usually earn US $30 every 3 months. Arnasih requests a loan to expand their business, so they are able to plant more and increase their profit. She is willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: To expand her business

loans.name: Tajudeen

texts.en: Tajudeen R. is 35 years old, married and has 4 children. She hails from Ajamgbadin in Lagos state, Nigeria. She is a stylist and also rents out DVD's. She has been a LAPO member for 2 years and needs the loan to buy generator.  This, she said, will help her serve her customer better. She thanks you.

loans.use: To buy a generator

loans.name: Saffiatu

texts.en: Saffiatu is 32 years old and married with 5 children.   She started her business 3 years ago by selling lengths of coton cloth (African prints) for clothing.  With two loans so far, she has diversified her business and has seen good profits that have enabled her to meet some family expenses as well as her repayments.  Married to a goldsmith, she says that her husband’s business is irregular so Saffiatu’s business is the primary source of income.  To expand her business further, she is requesting a loan of $350.

loans.use: Continue to expand and diversify her business by adding addtional items for sale

loans.name: Christiana

texts.en: Christiana S. is 50 years old, married and has 5 children. She hails from Ishashi in Lagos state, Nigeria. She sells foodstuffs and has been in business since 2002. She requests the loan to enable her to buy more foodstuffs for sale and boost her business.

loans.use: To buy more foodstuffs

loans.name: Fatmata

texts.en: Fatmata is 36 years old and married with 5 children.   With five children, all in school, Fatmata needs to help generate enough income to meet the family’s expenses.  Her business income supplements her husband’s meager income. She sells cosmetics in the open-air market of Magburaka in Sierra Leone.  She is requesting a loan of $175 to expand her stock.

loans.use: add to her stock of cosmetics for sale so that she can increase her profits

loans.name: Rehema

texts.en:
Rehema N. is a young businesswoman who is running two business: a small food stall-and-café where she serves lunch and dinner, and a livestock business, where she raises and sells chickens (don’t worry, there are no chickens in the kitchen, unless of course you want a piece of tender tandoori chicken – a speciality in Dar es Salaam!). Rehema requires a loan of $700 to expand her café business (it seems she has enough chickens for the moment, but we’ll keep you posted!).

SELFINA is engaged in economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through a leasing and leaseback facility, as a practical way to achieve economic and social emancipation of women.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro Leasing. Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus termed not creditworthy by financial institutions, as they lack tangible collateral assets. This leads to poor financial support, hence poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes.

SELFINA buys and leases equipment to women. Where a client needs working capital, SELFINA buys equipment from the said client, extending a loan to her, and then leases beck the same equipment – a process called sale and leaseback.

loans.use: To purchase supplies for the cafe.

loans.name: Liz Delzi

texts.es:
Liz is a multitalented woman and has always worked with the purpose of forging a better future for her children. She wants to provide them with economic security. Liz is a single mother and has managed to overcome many obstacles with dignity and without the support of her husband. Her daily motivation is to procure a promising future for her children by way of her work. She has always been able to count on the support of her loving mother in every one of the activities that she has decided to take on. Liz is dedicated to the upbringing and feeding of animals. On the weekends she takes advantage of fairs in neighboring towns to sell typical meals. During her free time she gives out beauty products. Now she wants to move forward with all of the projects she has in mind and she wants to finance a tourist recreational area so that she can secure herself economically and get on with nursing animals. Support this hard-working mother that always wishes to give her best.

Translated from Spanish by Geoff Rubin, Kiva volunteer.

Liz, es una mujer multifacética, siempre ha trabajado con el propósito de forjar un futuro mejor para sus hijos y brindarles seguridad económica. Ella es madre soltera y con mucha dignidad ha logrado superar grandes cosas, sola sin el apoyo de su pareja; su motivación diaria es otorgarles a sus dos hijos un futuro prometedor a través de su trabajo y para lograr sus propósitos siempre contó con el respaldo de su querida madre en cada una de las actividades que decidió realizar. Liz en su compañía está dedicada a la crianza y engorde de animales y los fines de semana aprovecha las ferias de cada pueblito aledaño al suyo para vender platos típicos y en las oportunidades y tiempos libres expende productos de belleza.Ahora quiere seguir adelante con todos los proyectos que tiene en mente y desea habilitar un recreo turístico en un terreno que tiene para establecerse mejor económicamente y por ello seguirá trabajando en la crianza de animales.Apoya a esta trabajadora madre que espera dar siempre lo mejor.

loans.use: To fund various ideas and establish a tourist restaurant

loans.name: Alicia

texts.es:
Alicia is a mother and a hard-working woman who is looking to forge a better future for her three cherished children. For this reason five years ago she decided to move to Hualhuas. Her husband is a native of that region and the decided to open a lodging area. They saw that this type of enterprise was in demand as the area was very touristy and busy. Now the entire family contributes to running and caring for the business. Thanks to the team-oriented business, harmony and cooperation are maintained between family members. Alicia watches with satisfaction the improvement of her home. In order to fulfill every request of the people who visit her city, Alicia has put in motion a plan so that every person this month that desires a room will have one. She desires to move forward with her plans. She is motivated by the immense love and commitment of her family. Let’s support Alicia to fulfill her noble desires.

Translated from Spanish by Geoff Rubin, Kiva volunteer.

Alicia, es una madre y a la vez una mujer emprendedora que está buscando forjar un mejor futuro para sus tres queridos hijos y es por esta razón que hace cinco años decidió radicar a Hualhuas debido a que su esposo es natural de ese lugar y decidieron aperturar un negocio de hospedajes ante la necesidad que percibieron por haberse convertido este lugar en un espacio muy turístico y visitado.Ahora toda la familia participa de la administración y atención de este negocio familiar y gracias a este desempeño en equipo se mantiene la armonía y cooperación de todos sus miembros.Alicia ve con satisfacción el sostenimiento de la economía de su hogar y para cumplir con cada uno de los requerimientos de las personas que visitan su ciudad ha puesto en marcha un plan a fin de que en este mes todos y cada una de las posibles solicitudes puedan ser cubiertas. Desea seguir adelante con sus planes motivada por el inmenso amor y compromiso de su familia.Apoyemos a Alicia a seguir adelante con estos nobles deseos.

loans.use: Increase lodging space and purchase of items for her project

loans.name: Nora Sulema

texts.es:
To buy more and a bigger variety of basic commodity products for her little store Compra de mayor cantidad y variedad de artículos de primera necesidad para la pequeña bodega Nora is a hardworking and determined woman. These qualities developed in her the desire to open a store at her home after getting married.

It has already been 18 years since she started her business and now she can gladly start to acknowledge the results of her arduous work. Indeed, her work allowed her, throughout the years, to offer a good quality of life to her 2 kids that are now studying at a college.

Her husband works as a driver and with his work, he contributes to give his family comfort and security.

Nora is very happy because she likes her store and to treat her clients well. These factors allow her to offer her clients a good service and her little store has developed into one of the best ones of the city.

Her economic situation has noticeably improved and Nora does not loose her vitality and optimism. It is with this improvement perspective that she continuously searches for new products that will allow her to increase her sales, and that is why she requests a loan.

Nora would like to invest purchasing more merchandise for her shop so her earnings continue to be one of the main sources of income of her household.

Let’s enable the request of this incredible and hardworking woman.

Translated from Spanish by Jimena Almendares Leistner, Kiva Volunteer.

Nora, es una mujer trabajadora y empeñosa, estas cualidades han suscitado en ella los deseos de aperturar una tienda en su propia casa después de haberse casado.

Ahora que han transcurrido dieciocho años observa con satisfacción el fruto de su arduo trabajo que le permitió durante todos estos años otorgarles bienestar a sus dos hijos, que ahora están estudiando en el colegio.

Su esposo por su parte trabaja como chofer y con su desempeño diario contribuye a generar bienestar y seguridad a su familia.

Nora está muy contenta porque le agrada atender su bodega y tratar gentilmente a sus clientes y debido a estos factores en el servicio su pequeña tiendita se ha convertido en una de las mejores de su ciudad.

Su situación económica ha mejorado notablemente y no pierde su vitalidad y optimismo para continuar y esta en constante búsqueda de nuevos productos que le permitan incrementar sus ventas, es por ello que solicita un préstamo a fin de invertirlos en la compra de más mercadería para implementar su bodega, con las ganancias seguirá siendo uno de los pilares en el sostén de su hogar.

Posibilitemos la petición de esta increíble y trabajadora mujer.

loans.use: To buy more and a bigger variety of basic commodity products for her little store

loans.name: Abelinda

texts.es:
Abelinda, es muy creativa y día a día se esmera en la fabricación de sus sahumerios.Todos los fines de semana se dispone a buscar los implementos y prepara con el palo santo molido y el papel reciclado, también molido, una masa, cuando está compacta los convierte en palitos, para finalmente forrarlos en papel de seda de diversos colores.Gracias a su desempeño puede sostener a su pequeño hijo, es madre soltera y anhela se convierta en un futuro en un hombre de bien muy útil a su sociedad. La rutina de trabajo de Abelinda es muy activa, después que ella elabora esos palitos para el sahumerio se va de viaje cada 15 días a la ciudad capital de su país, donde también comercializa, ollas de la abundancia, sólo por temporadas. Los artículos que desplaza, los ofrece con plazos de pago y en grandes cantidades. Hace dieciocho años por consejos de su querido hermano se inició en la comercialización de estos artículos y son los meses de Diciembre y octubre en el que tiene mayores demandas, ahora tiene que aprovechar al máximo estas solicitudes y desea seguir haciéndolo motivada por las ganancias que percibe con el fin de establecerse en un lugar céntrico para vender sus productos.Solicita un préstamo para comprar los insumos y más mercadería para esta época navideña. Abelinda recurre a vuestra ayuda para concretar cada uno de sus planes.

Translated from Spanish by Kiva Volunteer, Wendy Wise

Abelinda, is very creative and day to day takes pains in the manufacturing of the incense she sells. Every weekend she goes off to look for the supplies and prepares the worn out wood and branches along with recycled paper. From this she makes a type of dough that eventually is turned into the small incense sticks which she then covers in silk paper of various colors. Thanks to her hard work she can support her small son, as she is a single mother and yearns for him to become a very useful and successful man in society. Abelinda’s work routine is very active. After she makes the incense, she goes away on a trip every 15 days to the capital city of her country, where also she sells, pots during certain seasons. The items she offers for sale, she does so using a lay-away and/or credit based process. Eighteen years ago, by advice of her beloved brother, she began selling these articles and December and October are the months which she has the most demand. Now she must take advantage of her high demand and wishes to continue doing so motivated by the gain that it brings in with the purpose of settling down in a central place to sell her products. She is requesting a loan to buy her inventory and more merchandise for this upcoming Christmas season. Abelinda is requesting our help to fulfill each one of her plans.

loans.use: Compra de insumos para la fabricación de sahumerios.

loans.name: Enma

texts.es:
Doña Enma, sigue trabajando porque le agrada hacerlo y es su vocación comercializar los artículos que produce. Ella proviene D. una familia netamente artesana, expertos en producir artículos tejidos, cada proceso en su elaboración son conocidos a la perfección por Doña Enma quien ha transmitido a sus siete hijos los conocimientos que adquirió D. sus padres y hermanos. Produce mantos, alfombras, chompas, en fin, todo lo que se pueda tejer y producir en los telares, para luego comercializarlos en la ciudad D. Lima y también en algunas ferias D. su localidad. Siempre ha realizado esta labor y con ayuda D. su esposo ha podido educar a sus hijos con valores y amor al trabajo. Sus inmensos deseos D. progreso la llevan a solicitar vuestra ayuda a través D. un préstamo con el objetivo D. adquirir mayor cantidad y variedad D. materia prima para seguir elaborando sus bellos artículos.Posibilitemos su petición para que su negocio se consoliD. y cobije esta navidad a su numerosa familia en el seno D. su humilD. hogar.

Translated from Spanish by Kiva Volunteer Wendy Wise

Enma continues working because she enjoys doing so and her vocation is commercializing the articles she produces. She comes from a mostly artisan family, experts in producing knit articles, and its art of perfection is well known by Enma. As a result she has transmitted that to her seven children. She makes rugs, tapestries and sweaters, and any thing else that can be knit and then sold in the city of Lima and local fairs. She has always done this for a living and with the help of her husband she has been able to proviD. her children with work values and love for their traD.. Her immense desires to progress have taken her to now solicit your help for a loan, with the intention of acquiring larger and more diverse quantities of material to continue manufacturing her beautiful articles. Let’s make her request possible so her business may grow and thus, allow her and her large family a merry Christmas in the warmth of their home.

loans.use: Compra de mayor cantidad y variedad de materia prima para la fabricación de bellos artículos./ Purchase large quantities and varieties of prime material to make beautiful products.

loans.name: Lilia

texts.es:
Lilia doesn’t feel satisfied with just being a loving mother. It has been 4 years since she observed the difficulties that her family went through, she decided to dedicate her self to sell meat and she started as an ambulatory sales person. Then quickly she established herself in a space inside of the most popular marketplace, which is close to her house. With consistency, good service, and honesty in which she sells her delicious orders and now she not only sells at her market place but also in an ambulatory way when she goes to the city of Lima. Her success in her business has filled her with satisfaction because together with her husband who works repairing the bodywork of cars, she is able to support and to make it so her three children are able to study at the university. Her kids do not remain indifferent to her hard work and they support their parents by helping in the activities that they do. All this strength and harmony comes from Lilia's wisdom and prudence in incorporating everyone in the team effort. She desires to continue and improve her business and this is why she requests a loan that she will invest in purchasing an electronic balance. With it she will provide greater exactness in the weight of her merchandise. Let's support Lilia so that she can keep moving forward and further strengthen her hardworking family.

Translated from Spanish by Edith and Johnny of San Roque High School, Kiva volunteers

Lilia, no se conforma con ser sólo una amorosa madre de familia, hace cuatro años al observar las dificultades por las que atravesaba su hogar decidió dedicarse a la venta de carne y empezó de manera ambulante, luego rápidamente se estableció en un puesto de ventas en el mercado más popular colindante a su casa, con la constancia, buen trato y honestidad que expende sus deliciosas carnes, el negocio y demandas se han acrecentado y ahora no sólo vende en el puesto del mercado sino también de manera ambulante cuando va periódicamente a la ciudad de Lima; este hecho la llena de mucha satisfacción porque junto a su esposo que se desempeña como reparador de carrocerías pueden sostener la economía de su hogar en beneficio de sus tres hijos que estudian en la universidad.Ellos no son indiferentes ante tanto trabajo y también apoyan ayudando a sus padres en las actividades que realizan. Toda esta fortaleza y armonía es mantenida por Lilia que como mujer sabia y prudente promueve un trabajo en equipo en cada uno de sus integrantes. Desea seguir adelante y mejorar su negocio y es por ello que solicita un préstamo que invertirá en la compra de una balanza electrónica, con ello ofrecerá mayor exactitud en el peso de su mercadería.Apoyemos a Lilia a seguir adelante para forjar una familia trabajadora.

loans.use: Buy an electronic scale and increase capital for her meat business.

loans.name: Edith

texts.es:
Edith is a hard working woman. Everyday she puts a lot of effort into her work. She works for the better of her eight year old daughter. Her daughter is her reason to live. These immense gains of progress motivate her to work in two establishments of sales. In one of them she sells gelatin. This way she administers her small store. Her mother was the former owner, but since then Edith had to take over because of her mother’s serious illness. This way she helps the economy in her household. Everyday she is available early in the morning dedicating herself to her daily labor. With her money she helps pay for her families necessities. She likes to establish trust with her customers and maintain good personal relationships, and this is why her store has grown enormously in spite of not being in a central location. Edith wants a loan for her inventory, this way she can help pay off her beloved mother’s medical bill.

Translated from Spanish by Johnny and Edith of San Roque High School, Kiva volunteers

Edith, es muy trabajadora y empeñosa día a día se esfuerza para trabajar en bien de su hija de ocho años que es toda su razón de vivir, estas inmensas ganas de progreso la motivan a trabajar en dos establecimientos de ventas, en uno de ellos vende gelatinas y de manera adicional administra su pequeña tienda en casa que fue traspasada por su madre quien por motivos de salud no puede dedicarse a la atención de la demanda de su público y ahora ella sume con mucho agrado estos negocios para solventar la economía de su hogar.Cada día ella se dispone muy temprano a dedicarse a las labores cotidianas de su hogar para luego atender su tienda ya lleva dedicándose a esto cerca de dos años y se siente muy satisfecha de disponer del dinero de sus ganancias para cubrir las necesidades de su familia, a Edith le agrada tratar con las personas y brindar un trato que infunde confianza y buenas relaciones personales con sus clientes y es por ello que su pequeña bodega a crecido enormemente a pesar de no estar ubicado en un lugar céntrico, con esto nos demuestra una vez más que el trato amable es indispensable en la atención.Edith solicita un préstamo para invertirlos en la compra de mercadería a fin de mejorar su tienda para ayudar con el tratamiento médico de su querida madre.

loans.use: Capital in order to acquire a greater quantity and variety of articles for her little shop.

loans.name: Lucy

texts.es:
Perseverance is practiced day to day in the life of Lucy, who always works to offer her two sons a better future. Even though she suffers from the separtation of her husband, for an infidelity case. She keeps her head up and continues trying to sustain her two young sons, who now are the reason of her existence and why she is willing to accept any sacrifice that offers them a better wellbeing. She is dedicated to selling CDs and DVDs of a variety of singers and genres. Before she had a commercial spot but due to the excessive cost of rent, she decided to do it in a traveling manor and together with her sister, who travels periodically to the capital to be able to sell theses items.
